debateinfo.title: COMMONWEALTH ELECTORAL AMENDMENT (REPRESENTATION IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES) BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr McGauran, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: The Commonwealth Electoral Amendment (Representation in the House of Representatives) Bill 2004 will ensure the transparency and certainty of the process for calculating the representative entitlement for each of the states and territories in the House of Representatives and will maintain at the next federal election the Northern Territory's current representation of two members.

On 19 February 2003, the Electoral Commissioner determined the number of members of the House of Representatives to be chosen by the states and territories at a general election. The determination was made under section 48 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918. The Electoral Commissioner determined that representation would change for Queensland, South Australia and the Northern Territory. Queensland gained an additional seat to have a total of 28 members, while South Australia and the Northern Territory each lost one seat. South Australia's representation has fallen to 11 seats. Only one member would be chosen for the Northern Territory as its population fell short of the quota by 295 people in order to retain its existing two seats.

The Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters inquired into representation of the territories in the House of Representatives following a request from the Special Minister of State, Senator the Hon. Eric Abetz, in July 2003. The committee's report, entitled Territory representation: report of the inquiry into increasing the minimum representation for the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory in the House of Representatives, was tabled on 1 December 2003.
This bill gives effect to the government response to the committee's report.

The committee made two recommendations aimed at ensuring both the transparency and certainty of the process used for the making of determinations for representation in the House of Representatives and a third recommendation for the government to set aside the Electoral Commissioner's determination of February 2003 to the extent that it applied to the Northern Territory.

The government agrees with the committee's findings that more transparency and certainty is required in the process of the Electoral Commissioner's determinations, particularly the use of the latest published statistics used in his calculations. Confusion has surrounded the concept of the latest statistics of the Commonwealth and specifically what are the relevant statistics provided by the Australian Statistician to the Electoral Commissioner to make his determination.

The absence of a legislative definition of the `latest' statistics of the Commonwealth has had the unintended consequence of providing the Australian Statistician, and to a lesser extent the Electoral Commissioner, with a degree of discretion when deciding which statistics will be used to determine state and territory representative entitlements in the House of Representatives.
The government therefore supports the committee's findings in these areas and agrees that legislative amendments be made to clearly specify that:

the statistics to be provided by the Australian Statistician for the purpose of the Electoral Commissioner's determination are to be the most recent set of statistics compiled and published by the Australian Statistician in a regular series under the Census and Statistics Act 1905;

the Australian Statistician should also provide the Electoral Commissioner information relating to the estimate of the net undercount for the ACT and the Northern Territory at the last census. Where there is a shortfall in either of the territories' calculations for an additional seat within two standard errors of the estimate of the net undercount—or margin of error—then the Electoral Commissioner is required to recalculate the territories' representative entitlements; and

the Electoral Commissioner is to make and publish his calculations, and any necessary adjustments required under the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 used in those calculations, within a specified period—one month after the first 12 months of the first sitting of the House of Representatives of a new parliament.

The government agrees that, whilst the existing basic principle for determining the number of members for the territories should not be disturbed, the confusion surrounding the use of the statistics in the February 2003 determination warrants that the Northern Territory's representation be maintained at its current level of two seats at the next election. It therefore supports the committee's recommendation to set aside the Electoral Commissioner's determination of 19 February 2003. This bill does this and provides that the most recent determination made before February 2003 is to apply to the Northern Territory.
This was a bipartisan report, and the government thanks the committee for the report.
I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum. At the same time, I also table the government response to the committee's report.
Debate (on motion by Mr Snowdon) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Hardgrave, and read a first time.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr HARDGRAVE
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: The Migration Amendment (Judicial Review) Bill 2004 reinstates the original intended operation of several procedural provisions relating to judicial review of migration decisions.

The government has grave concerns about the growing number of unmeritorious judicial review applications being made. These have led to increasing costs and delays in the judicial review process. Increased delays have encouraged many applicants to litigate to the maximum regardless of the legal merits. This is solely to delay their departure from Australia.
These concerns need to be addressed urgently. The opposition also shares these concerns and has been exploring ways to streamline judicial review of migration matters.

The government believes that the restoration of these procedural provisions for judicial review of migration matters will reduce the number of migration judicial review applications by approximately 25 to 30 per cent. This would also reduce the government's litigation costs by about $5 to $7 million per year, to save the taxpayer. This dividend could be used to assist persons in greater need, such as refugees who are being resettled in Australia as part of our offshore humanitarian program—a program that has no peer elsewhere in the world.

These statistics do speak for themselves. In 1995-96 there were 596 judicial review applications before the Commonwealth courts, compared with approximately 6,900 in 2002-03. That is an exponential growth. As a consequence, the litigation expenditure for my department exceeded $19 million in 2002-03.

The amendments being made by this bill to the Migration Act 1958 follow the completion of the Attorney-General's recent migration litigation review. These changes are straightforward and will have a significant impact on reducing the large numbers of unmeritorious migration related judicial review applications. The government will be announcing its response to other matters in the review shortly.
The amendments will restore the following key procedural elements of the migration judicial review scheme:
Time limits on judicial review applications;
Only the High Court, the Federal Court and the Federal Magistrates Court will be able to hear judicial review of migration applications; and
An applicant will not be able to seek judicial review if merits review of the primary decision is available.

In restricting the time limits within which judicial review applications are to be made, the government has a duty to provide a discretion for the courts to extend those limits beyond the 28-day period, for a further period of up to 56 days, where that is in the interests of the administration of justice. I think this is a fair discretion that we offer to the courts.
I emphasise that these amendments will not impact on the existing grounds for judicial review or change the basis of the lawfulness of a decision—they are only procedural in nature.

The judicial review requirements being restored by this bill were first introduced into, and passed by, the parliament in 1992. They were amended to operate in relation to `privative clause decisions' in judicial review amendments that were passed in September 2001.
The intention of the privative clause was to restrict judicial review grounds to only a few specified errors.

The constitutionality of the privative clause was challenged in the High Court in plaintiff s157/2002 v. Commonwealth of Australia [2003] (s157). While the privative clause was found to be constitutional, it did not protect decisions which contained a jurisdictional error.

This has meant that a `privative clause decision' is the only one that does not contain a jurisdictional error. These procedural provisions have no practical effect as a court must undertake a full review of the claims challenged to determine if those restrictions apply.
The existing time limits, exclusive jurisdiction and restrictions on judicial review only apply to a `privative clause decision'.

As a result courts have to undertake complete judicial review of all migration decisions, regardless of the amount of time that has passed, to determine the lawfulness of the decision. Approximately 40 per cent of all current applications are being made outside the time limits specified in the existing provisions, with some being lodged up to six years after the original visa decision under challenge.

The bill will amend the definition of `privative clause decision' in the act so that it includes a `purported decision'. This means that procedural requirements in relation to time limits within which applications can be made will apply to all actions taken under the Migration Act.

The definition of `privative clause decision' for the purpose of section 474, which has been interpreted as setting the judicial review grounds for migration matters, is specifically excluded from the broader `privative clause decision' definition in section 5. This means that the grounds of judicial review are not affected by these amendments.
The objective of the original reforms was to ensure certainty and efficiency in resolving migration review applications. This bill reinstates that original intention.

By strengthening the procedural amendments the government is removing the incentive for an applicant to pursue litigation as an end in itself—to delay their departure from Australia. Upholding the time limits will ensure that applicants will no longer be able to delay indefinitely the final determination of their migration matters.

Given the importance of the amendments, and demonstrating the government's continual, yet urgent, commitment to implement effective reforms to the migration litigation system, the government intends that the bill will be proclaimed to commence as soon as possible after royal assent.
I commend the bill to the chamber and I present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Stephen Smith) adjourned.

debateinfo.title: EXCISE AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (COMPLIANCE MEASURES) BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Ross Cameron, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: This bill amends the Excise Act 1901 to improve compliance and administration arrangements.

The ATO is responsible for the high level of risk management required to protect the revenue and the excise legislation provides considerable controls to enable the ATO to ensure compliance with the law.

Diversion of goods delivered for exportation is a significant risk for excise revenue. However, movement of excisable goods for exportation may occur under the existing provisions without the permission of the ATO. Accordingly, the ATO is unable to apply to these goods the usual compliance and revenue protection measures that it is able to apply to all other movement of excisable goods.

The amendments in the bill ensure that ATO permission is required for delivery of excisable goods for exportation. The bill extends to the exportation of excisable goods the provisions that enable the duty equivalent to be called up where a person entrusted with excisable goods fails to keep the goods safely or cannot satisfactorily account for them.

Under this bill current provisions that regulate the movement of tobacco leaf will be extended to tobacco seed and plant and permissions relating to movement of these goods for exportation will be required.

This bill also extends the criteria that enable immediate destruction of seized forfeited goods. Currently goods must be perishable and a danger to public health. However, in most cases seized excisable goods and tobacco seed, plant or leaf do not satisfy both the perishable and danger to public health criteria. The seized goods may be perishable only without special storage arrangements, or may not be perishable but do not meet any relevant standards that would enable them to be returned to the market.

The amendments enable seized goods to be destroyed immediately where they are perishable or a danger to public health or safety or do not meet any applicable standards. The amendments provide for the use of evidentiary certificates in proceedings relating to those goods and extend the compensation provisions to include where the court is satisfied the grounds for disposing of the goods did not exist.

Finally, the bill amends the confidentiality provisions of the Excise Act to enable information about licences, permissions and remission of duty arrangements to be made available to a second person dealing with, or proposing to deal with, the goods covered by the licence, permission or remission documents.

The present confidentiality provisions prevent such information from being disclosed to a second person dealing with the goods. However, this information is at times a prerequisite for a second person to comply with the law. The amendments enable the information relating to licences, permissions and remission arrangements to be made available to a second person where it is considered necessary to ensure compliance with the excise legislation.
Full details of the measures in the bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum.
I commend the bill and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Stephen Smith) adjourned.

debateinfo.title: VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS AMENDMENT (DIRECT DEDUCTIONS AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mrs Vale, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: This bill gives effect to a number of minor policy measures that will enhance services to veterans and their dependants, continuing this government's commitment to improving the repatriation system to ensure it operates as effectively as possible in meeting the needs of the Australian veteran community.
Notably, amendments in this legislation will:
enable recipients of the veteran disability pension and war widow's/widower's pension to arrange direct deduction payments;
increase the Victoria Cross allowance and commence indexation of this special benefit by the consumer price index;

introduce automatic eligibility for the war widow's/widower's income support supplement to partners who received their social security age pension or wife pension through the Department of Veterans' Affairs; and
ensure eligibility for the partner service pension includes certain partners of veterans living on Norfolk Island.

Other amendments will correct minor policy flaws in relation to the calculation of disability pension arrears and rent assistance, and the recovery of certain overpayments. Parts of this bill will also align the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 with social security law in relation to the deeming of certain income and assets, the income and assets treatment of superannuation benefits and compensation recovery provisions.

Currently, direct deduction arrangements are available for recipients of the service pension or the war widow's/widower's income support supplement. Such arrangements allow veterans and war widows/widowers to have deductions made from their benefits for regular payments such as rent to state housing authorities.

These arrangements are not currently available for disability pensions or the war widow's/widower's pension. This bill will extend the direct deduction provisions to allow these pensioners to arrange such deductions from their fortnightly payments.

This bill will enhance the allowance paid to our two surviving recipients of the Victoria Cross. The Victoria Cross allowance is currently $2,808 per year and is paid annually in advance. Under these amendments, the allowance will be increased by 15 per cent to $3,230 per year, and it will be subject to annual indexation in line with movements in the consumer price index. These amendments reflect changes in the allowance provided to British VC recipients by the British government and recognise the special place held by Australia's Victoria Cross winners. The amendments will also make minor reforms to the provisions for decoration allowance.
Amendments in this bill will enhance support for veterans' partners who received the social security age pension or wife pension through my department.

On the death of a veteran, where the veterans' death is accepted as being related to their service, the partner becomes eligible for the war widow's/widower's pension. However, they currently are required to lodge a formal claim to receive the war widow's/widower's income support supplement.

This bill will provide automatic eligibility for partners in these circumstances to receive the income support supplement, removing an administrative burden from widows/widowers coming to terms with the loss of their partner.

In a further measure of support for veterans' partners, the bill will ensure eligibility for the partner service pension includes certain partners who are resident in Norfolk Island. These amendments correct an anomaly in the provisions that meant certain partners resident in Norfolk Island were not eligible for the partner service pension.

Many of these amendments represent relatively small changes to our repatriation legislation. However, this `finetuning' of the Veterans' Entitlements Act is important to those members of the veteran community who will benefit from these changes, and the government sees this legislation as continuing to deliver on its commitment to those who serve in the defence of our nation.
I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Stephen Smith) adjourned.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Financial Services, I present the committee's report, incorporating a dissenting report, entitled Corporations Amendment Regulations 2003 (batch 6); Corporations Amendment Regulations 2003-04 (batch 7) and draft regulations—Corporations Amendment Regulations 2004 (batch 8), together with the evidence received by the committee.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

subdebate.1.para: Consideration resumed from 24 March.

talk.start.para: —It is important for the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Teaching Profession) Bill 2004 to be considered in detail. I am delighted and surprised that the Minister for Education, Science and Training looks like he might now participate in this debate after our encouragement yesterday. We said that, if the government was so strongly of the view that this was an education matter, maybe it would be appropriate for the minister for education to actually have something to say on this matter.

speech.para: Unfortunately, in the summing-up from the government, not only did the issues that were raised by the opposition not get adequately addressed but also a couple of other issues were raised which throw some light on the desperation that the government has in trying to find other examples to justify its case. I think it is important that, whichever minister is responding, the issue of the recent suggestion by the Attorney-General that the Western Australian government has been offering male-only scholarships be addressed. It is quite absurd. A statement has been issued by the Department of Education and Training itself. It clearly states that it was issued by the Western Australian Director-General of the Department of Education and Training, Mr Paul Albert, on 21 March, which was, I think, at the time that the government started asserting that the Western Australians had offered these scholarships. The specific, direct quote is that the Department of Education and Training does not offer teaching scholarships exclusively for males.

The Attorney yesterday tabled a six- or seven-page information guide about these scholarships that are offered to students and had the audacity to say that this supported his claim that the government of Western Australia offered male-only scholarships. The section he has highlighted actually specifically says that the department is seeking applications from people who qualify in various areas. This is under the title, `Areas of need', and there are six areas of need, of which male primary teachers is one. Obviously, it is an important one, but the suggestion that calling for technology and enterprise teachers, Indonesian teachers, special needs teachers, mathematics teachers and physical science teachers as well as male primary teachers is somehow offering exclusive scholarships to men is, I think, completely bizarre. Obviously the government is quite happy to go around and misrepresent other governments and departments for the way that they are trying to deal with this as a practical issue and area of need.

Let me lay out clearly for the minister the issues that we have. We agree with the government that it is important to get more men into primary schools. We agree that the aim and stated objective of the government is a good one. We think that there are many initiatives that can be taken to encourage more men into teaching and to make sure that we are getting quality teachers of both genders into our schools. But Labor do not agree that this is the right mechanism. Labor's opposition is not about protecting the Sex Discrimination Act for the sake of it. The Sex Discrimination Act is there for a purpose. If there is some social reason that everyone supports for it to be changed, we accept that. We just do not believe that this is the reason or the opportunity to do that, because we do not believe that the government has made out the case for why this particular change to the act will deliver an outcome that everybody says is a decent one. Even though the minister is here to participate in this debate now, I do not think that he will be able to present a more convincing argument than any of the people who spoke in support of this bill, who seemed much more interested in talking about affirmative action in the Labor Party and all sorts of other issues but not very interested in talking about how this bill will actually deliver the objective that the government has.

We have already gone through what we think would be more effective measures, but it is important to lay on the record clearly that our objection is that we believe the existing act does provide sufficiently for sensible measures to be taken. This has been proven by the fact that the Catholic Education Office and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission have been able to resolve their particular issue. We do not believe that this bill is necessary anymore. We think that the existing exemption provisions are flexible and that the special measures provisions can also be used for a multitude of other initiatives that people might want to pursue in this area. We do not believe that you should narrow the Sex Discrimination Act and introduce permanent exemptions lightly—particularly not, as I say, in a situation where the instance which gave rise to this bill is now resolved. We do not think that the bill is necessary any more. (Extension of time granted)

The exemption that would be introduced by this bill is not one that would operate in the same way as other exemptions granted by HREOC under the existing act. It will be universal, permanent and unconditional, and we do not know how it will be used and what it will be used for in the future. I am interested to see whether the minister can answer this question. Yesterday, when the Attorney was in a press conference with the human rights commission on another matter, he was asked whether this type of exemption or another change like this would be introduced in other areas in the future. The Attorney answered: `Well, the fact is we've been asked to do this and we haven't been asked to do other things, so we don't need to.'

I am sure that the minister will have seen this article. His photo is in this particular edition of Catholic Weekly, so I am sure he will have seen it. On the front page, Dr Kelvin Canavan emphasises that, contrary to recent media reports, the Catholic Education Office had not requested a change to the Sex Discrimination Act. When I said to the Attorney, `You just said that you have been asked to do this, but you have not been asked in other areas,' the minister at the table will be interested to know that the Attorney answered, `Oh yes, I was asked to do this.' I then asked, `Who were you actually asked by, Attorney, when the Catholic Education Office is on the public record saying that they did not ask for this change?' and he had to admit that he had been asked by the minister for education. So we now have ministers of this government saying, `We've been asked to introduce legislation, therefore we are doing it. We're being really responsive to the community,' when in fact the minister was asked by his colleagues to do it. `We have been asked by the community' is an extraordinary excuse for the need for this legislation when it turns out that they have actually been asked by the minister for education himself.

Let us get some honesty into this debate. The government has decided to do this of its own initiative. We would like the minister to tell us what else this provision could be used for and whether he has any views on questions that were not answered in the minister's summing up, which include: will this have a negative impact on the general provisions that exist in the act, and will having a specific exemption in this area narrow the application of the other provisions? The latter question is a serious consideration that should be taken into account if you are going to change general legislation which prohibits discrimination. I am sure the minister for education, who is at the table, does not want the Sex Discrimination Act to be weakened in any of the other ways that it applies in areas that he oversees. I am sure that he does not think it is appropriate for students, teachers or others at universities to be discriminated against in their employment or in a whole range of things that are covered by this act. I would like to know whether the minister is comfortable with the fact that this bill could weaken the other provisions of the act. If he wants to be the minister responsible for introducing a bill that will weaken the rest of the Sex Discrimination Act, obviously that is an issue for him.

There has been no evidence presented for, and there is not any logic to, the argument that the Sex Discrimination Act itself is what is preventing men from entering the teaching profession. It is not the barrier. It is not the cause. The real issues of why men are not entering the profession are not being addressed by this legislation. It is like saying—and I am sure the minister for education would be familiar with this from his previous life—there are not enough doctors in the country, so we will legislate to give all doctors free train trips to the country so that they can get there. That free train travel might be nice, but it is not going to be enough to change their minds about wanting to live in the country to practice medicine, and certainly the cost of the train travel is not what is deterring them from going there.

The logic is just not made out for why the initiative that is being supported in this bill will deliver the outcome that everybody agrees is important. I think that it does highlight that there is a personal agenda and some posturing that is going on in this area. The minister wants to look good about doing something to help get men into teaching, which we think is important, but we would like to do something more than look good—we would like to actually deliver on this. We do not believe that this bill is going to deliver, so it is really important that the minister substantiate how it is that he believes this bill will deliver anything. Given that the minister is here at the table, I would like him to answer how he can pretend that the government is acting on a parliamentary report called Boys: getting it right, when that full, detailed report and its 24 recommendations do not make a single suggestion that it is the Sex Discrimination Act that should be changed and those recommendations—I think bar one—have not been acted upon by this government, even with 18 months to two years time to consider doing them. (Extension of time granted)

We ask that the government withdraw this legislation based on the fact that the driving reason, the particular circumstance that the government was looking at, has been resolved and that the existing legislation gives plenty of flexibility for other educational organisations who might want to pick up similar or possibly different initiatives that would deal with providing some incentive to get men into teaching. We urge the government that, rather than pursue this legislation, they actually revisit the report that the minister for education was involved in drafting as part of the Boys: getting it right report and look at the range of initiatives that could have some serious impact in this area and result in better educational outcomes for boys. We urge the government to stop playing games with this important issue. Do not use the Sex Discrimination Act as a diversion; let us get involved in a cross-party way in initiatives that will really make a difference to get men into schools and might have an impact on boys' education rather than use this as a diversion for the fact that a lot of money, energy and resources are not being put into real measures that could deliver something for our boys in schools.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr NELSON
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: —The member for Gellibrand has put a number of questions which she wants me to answer on behalf of the government. One thing she said was that the government had taken its own initiative. Yes, as Australia's Minister for Education, Science and Training, I did take this initiative following four years of close examination of the issue of boys and boys' education in Australian schools and on behalf of not only Australian parents, mothers in particular, but future generations of Australians who will be done a great disservice by young men who leave the education system ill prepared for life and ill prepared for their relationships with others, including and especially their relationships with women.

speech.para: The AttorneyGeneral said that he or we had been approached. He meant that he and his predecessor, the member for Tangney when AttorneyGeneral, had been approached—by me. What happened was that the Catholic Education Office on 30 August 2002 applied to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission for an exemption from the Sex Discrimination Act for something that the average Australian would think quite unremarkable: in order to get more men into primary school teaching, they would like to offer male-only scholarships.

Why is this amendment being proposed by the government and why is it so important? I can assure you that it relates to a number of things. The first is that our boys, our sons, are falling seriously behind where they were 35 years ago educationally in key literacy benchmarks, especially in adolescence. They are behind girls somewhere between three to four percentage points in operational literacy right across the cognitive curriculum from early primary school to the end of secondary school. We should not be concerned about the fact that girls are exceeding the educational outcomes of boys in year 12 in more than 90 per cent of courses that are assessed at the year 12 level. It is long past time that girls be able to fulfil and meet their own educational potential and in many cases exceed that of boys; noone should be concerned about that. But the fundamental concern is that boys are not doing as well as boys were 35 years ago and that boys are represented by more than two to one in the bottom 25 per cent of educational outcomes throughout school.

To add to that, boys are represented in close to 100 per cent of disciplinary programs in coeducational schools. Nationally they represent 80 per cent of students in school disciplinary programs and expulsions. They are more likely to be involved in assault and in drug related incidents; they are three times more likely to suffer injury and death in a motor vehicle accident; they are more likely to suffer spinal cord damage; and, for a variety of reasons, they are five times more likely to take their own life.

Education is about many things, and many speakers have said throughout the debate that a quality, well-trained, enthusiastic and committed teacher, irrespective of gender, is at the heart of a good educational outcome—and they are right: in terms of achieving pure educational outcomes, it is about the quality of the teaching. But education is much more than simply transferring a thirst for learning to young people and the transferring of skills and knowledge; it is ultimately about building well-rounded human beings. Both men and women bring to the classroom qualities specific to their gender which are critically important to build character and personal development into the lives of our sons and our daughters.

I will give an example of the reality that we face. I had the privilege to chair the boys' inquiry, the parliamentary inquiry, for its first eight or nine months. (Extension of time granted) Amongst the many things that stood out during that time were two men with a lot of life experience and I think psychology degrees who ran a consultancy called COOL—and I cannot remember what that acronym stands for. These fellows were called into schools to deal with problems with adolescent boys in middle and secondary school. At the time of giving evidence, they had dealt with 160 boys in government and non-government schools. They described in some detail the problems that were besetting—I realise that this is of some humour to the opposition—these boys, which went from disengagement in education right through to self-harm. I asked them, `Of the 168 boys with whom you have now dealt, how many have a father or a father figure in their lives?' They paused for a moment before answering and then said, `None, not one.'

The reality we face in this country is that only one in five primary school teachers today are men. Only 18 per cent of those who are training to be primary school teachers are men. In Catholic education, only 14 per cent of those who are teaching in Catholic schools in the state of New South Wales are men. In fact, 15 per cent of public primary schools in New South Wales do not have a single man on campus other than a gardener, and in many cases they do not even have that. Through no fault of their own, one in seven Australian children are living in fatherless families. There are many causes of fatherlessness—for example, death, divorce, separation or abandonment.

There are also children growing up in fathered families. Do you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the average father spends six minutes a day with his son and 14 seconds in meaningful conversation? The average teacher, however, spends 30 hours a week with those same children. In other words, whether they come from fatherless or fathered families, it is critically important that our boys—and our girls—have role models in the formative years of their education because, if they do not, what they are doing is adopting the hypermasculine role models that are paraded before them by the media on a daily basis, such as footballers or rock stars. Many boys have a sense of aimlessness—not necessarily educational aimlessness but aimlessness in their own masculinity. The Leader of the Opposition, to his credit, has focused on the issue of boys and masculinity.

What we have here is a practical way—no-one has ever suggested, and I have never suggested, that it is the only way—to address the problem of the inadequate number of men in teaching by amending the Sex Discrimination Act. The response to this emerging crisis needs to be a full suite of measures, and we have put half a million dollars into examining, for example, the way in which exams are structured at school. Boys often know the answers but they do not understand the questions. I will be announcing shortly that we have also established, on an ongoing basis, 30 clusters for school education which are models of best practice in boys' education throughout Australia. I have also asked the Australian Council of Deans of Education what they think ought to be done to get more men into teaching.

I will run through the sequence of events leading to this bill, because it is helpful. On 3 March 2003 the application by the Sydney Catholic Education Office was rejected by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. I noticed a report on this in the Sydney Daily Telegraph. I did not contact the Catholic Education Office; I recall asking one of my staff to make some inquiries to confirm that the media report was accurate and I was informed that it was. I then raised the matter with the then Attorney-General, the member for Tangney, and I said, `I think that this is absurd.'

I explained the situation: the Catholic Education Office wants to offer 12 scholarships to attract more men to teaching, and there is a very important point in this. The proposal is that a young man who is thinking about going to university—who might be thinking about doing science, engineering, arts or some other course—might then, because a scholarship is being offered to get men into primary school teaching in Catholic schools, decide to apply for teacher education training at UTS, Sydney University or some other university. (Extension of time granted). That male student would then be accepted or not accepted into teacher education purely on the basis of merit. In other words, if his tertiary entrance score were inadequate, he would not get a place. But if on merit he did get a place then he would have a scholarship provided by the Catholic Education Office for which he would then be required to teach in a Catholic primary school for a number of years.

The average Australian—who is following Guy Sebastian and Delta Goodrem or the guys that are going to be up at Mount Panorama in October—looking at the footy results in the Herald Sun today would say, `Yes, that sounds pretty sensible to me.' But, blow me down, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission says, `No, you can't do that.' This was reported in the media on 3 March. I spoke to the then Attorney-General and then on 20 March 2003 I wrote to the Attorney-General officially to ask what options we had under the Sex Discrimination Act to overcome what is an absurd proposition and a problem for which our sons are paying an enormous price. The Attorney-General then corresponded with me and set out the options. In the West Australian on 20 May 2003 there is a report on page 6 which says:

quote.para: Federal Education Minister Brendan Nelson wants the Sex Discrimination Act to be changed to address a shortage of male primary school teachers.

speech.para: This was 20 May 2003; that is some time ago. Rather interestingly, in the same article the Western Australian education minister, Alan Carpenter, is quoted as saying:

quote.para: ... he welcomed any move that would complement the Government's—

speech.para: his government's—

quote.para: recruitment policies over male teachers.

speech.para: So we found out that the Western Australian government had been offering scholarships for men. This is very interesting, because the member for Gellibrand sought to present this material as evidence that the Sex Discrimination Act does not have to be changed. The Western Australian government—what I am about to present—did this because it thought it was plain commonsense. Unlike the Catholic Education Office, it did not actually go to the human rights commission for an exemption because it thought no sane person would be opposed to it. So in the information guide for final year teaching scholarships for 2003-04 put out by the Western Australian Department of Education and Training—it covers farming and teaching scholarships, physical sciences and mathematics, with a closing date of August 2003—it says:

quote.para: 2004 Final Year Teaching Scholarships:
A. Areas of need ...
B. Physical sciences and mathematics

speech.para: This is the information for students about scholarships that are available. There are six categories, as the member for Gellibrand helpfully points out. The department is seeking applications from people who will qualify as: technology and enterprise teachers, Indonesian teachers—presumably teachers of Indonesian, not Indonesians—special needs education teachers, mathematics teachers, physical science teachers and male primary teachers. What qualifications might you have to have to apply for a scholarship to be a male primary teacher? I do not want to reduce the standard of debate in the House, but I present this question to the opposition and certainly to the gallery: what would be a fundamental criterion to be eligible for a male primary school teaching scholarship? You also have to meet the character and other recruitment requirements of the department.

Presumably, a part of the requirement for a male primary school teaching scholarship would be to be a man—in other words, to have a Y chromosome. That is what is being promoted by the Western Australian government. No-one complained about this. The reason this has not come before the human rights commission is that no-one complained about it, and no sane person would. The education minister in Western Australia has actually pointed out that it is working. For the first time this year more men are going into Western Australian public primary schools as a result of these scholarships. It is actually working. It is interesting that the member for Jagajaga, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, put out a media release on Sunday 21 March 2004, which says:

quote.para: There are no male only scholarships for teaching offered by the WA Education and Training Department.

speech.para: I beg your pardon? Of course there are. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I have to rise in this consideration in detail stage to ask that the Minister for Education, Science and Training try to address the questions that have been raised by the opposition during this debate and that he bother to get the detail right if he wants to contribute to the debate. It is an absolute disgrace that the government would use as an argument to change the Sex Discrimination Act the fact that the Western Australian government did not seek an exemption. It shows that the minister has no idea that state governments are not bound by the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Act. It is a basic `Sex Discrimination 101' issue and it raises the complete lack of attention to detail that this government has brought to this entire issue.

speech.para: If the government wants to change the Sex Discrimination Act to deliver an outcome, it should at least bother to find out what the act covers, what is already included in the act, who is bound by it and who is not. Do not, minister, stand up here and say that the reason that the Western Australian government did not seek an exemption is that no-one complained about it. The reason is that they are not covered by the act. The minister is quite wrong. This highlights the lack of detailed attention that the government has given to this issue.

A statement from the WA department of education clearly says that they do not offer teaching scholarships exclusively for males. Of course, some of the people who are going to receive scholarships under these six categories will be men and some will not. Some will be both male teachers and Indonesian teachers. Some will be technology teachers and male teachers. Some will be females who fit into the other categories. It is wrong to pretend that this system is aimed exclusively at males. I seek leave to table that document.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —It would be useful if the minister read that document before replying on this issue to see that it is the department, not the politicians who are entering this debate, which is explaining that it does not offer exclusively male scholarships. It highlights a point that the minister has made that we are in serious agreement on—this is a complex issue and there are a range of measures that could be taken. The government will have the opposition's support for measures that are actually going to deliver some benefit.

speech.para: The minister said in his reply that he has been studying this issue for four years and he has been committed to it for a long time. He would know—perhaps I will have to table this too—that his own report, Boys: getting it right, has 24 recommendations in it, none of which suggest that the Sex Discrimination Act should be amended or that that would even deliver any benefit. The Sex Discrimination Act is discussed in this report. It is not as if the committee did not deal with the issue. It dealt with it and made a decision that it was not going to recommend changing the act.

Perhaps the minister might explain why the government would start with this measure when there are a whole lot of other recruitment strategies and a whole lot of other things that could be done without us changing the Sex Discrimination Act. Surely we should have some resistance to changing it as a first measure rather than a last measure. Surely we should seek to do things that are within our existing laws if we possibly can and if they are going to be effective, especially when we have not even been asked to change it by anybody. As we now find out, the only person that has asked is the minister, perhaps from a well-motivated interest in trying to get more men into schools, which we have encouraged him in. He has even acknowledged the Leader of the Opposition's interest in this.

To rush to change the Sex Discrimination Act as one of the first things you would do is completely absurd. The government and the minister must give us a reason why this would deliver any outcome. As the minister says, it might encourage some men to go into teaching instead of into other courses. This report goes into great detail about the problem being retaining men in classrooms. So what is going to happen with these young men who are attracted to teaching if no other measures are put in place to keep them there? We know that men are more quickly being appointed as principals and therefore being moved out of the classroom.

Why won't the minister for education withdraw this bill? I hope that he will answer this in his next response. Why won't he talk with us about initiatives that would really make a difference to meet an objective that we all agree is an important one? Let us get serious about what we can do. Let us look at the sorts of detailed recommendations and initiatives that are in this report that the minister knows would make much more difference. Let us forget about posturing and changing or narrowing the Sex Discrimination Act when it is not going to deliver the outcome that the government seeks. (Time expired)

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr NELSON
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: —I will respond to a couple of the specific points made. Firstly, the Australian government Attorney-General has received advice on the male only scholarships being offered by the Western Australian Department of Education and Training that it may have in fact contravened the federal Sex Discrimination Act. That is ultimately a question for the courts. If a complaint of discrimination were to be made, if someone were to complain about the male only scholarships—apparently in the world of the member for Gellibrand and the Labor Party, women are eligible to apply for male only scholarships, but I will deal with that in a moment—the question is going to be resolved by the courts. Section 22 of the Sex Discrimination Act makes it unlawful to discriminate against a person on the basis of their sex in the provision of goods and services.

speech.para: In fact, as a result of this I have actually had to ask my department to seek advice from the Australian Government Solicitor as to whether we, the Australian government, are contravening the Sex Discrimination Act because we are offering specific bonuses to attract women into non-traditional trades—$1,100 per employee to take on female apprentices in specific trades.

As far as the Boys: getting it right report is concerned, it recommended scholarships for both men and women. The Deputy Chair of the committee that conducted the inquiry, the Labor member for Port Adelaide, was asked why they had done this, because the journalist who wrote the story for the Sydney Morning Herald on 20 March 2003 thought, `This is odd: why would you offer scholarships for women as well as men when you actually want to get men?' The report says:

quote.para: Rod Sawford, deputy chair of the inquiry, acknowledges the male only scholarships would have been preferable.

speech.para: He acknowledged it would be preferable and he said:

quote.para: We thought the discrimination laws would be a problem. That's why we said 50 per cent.

speech.para: In other words, the committee recommended what it did not because that is what it really wanted to recommend but because it quite rightly perceived that otherwise it would be in breach of the Sex Discrimination Act. So what we are trying to do here is make an amendment which would allow a bipartisan committee that had spent the best part of two years looking at boys' education to make the recommendation that it thought it ought to make.

Last Friday I had one of those surreal experiences and I said to myself, `What kind of country are we living in?' The Sex Discrimination Commissioner, the Catholic Education Office and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission made an announcement. They said that the problem with the Catholic Education Office had now been resolved—that the 12 male only scholarship problem had been resolved. I thought, `Oh, that's great,' and I said to my staff, `What have they resolved? How have they resolved it?' Apparently the way we get more men into primary school teaching in Australia is that we have to get more women as well. So we have the Leader of the Opposition, Mark Latham, running the greengrocer's shop in Green Valley. The Catholic Education Office turns up and says, `We need 12 apples.' He says, `Great, no worries. Here's 12 apples.' But then he says, `By the way, you've got to take 12 oranges as well.' And Brother Canavon says, `Oh, thanks a lot, mate, but we've got plenty of oranges at home. We don't need any more oranges, but only 14 per cent of the fruit at home is apples. We need apples.' And Labor says, `No, you're not getting out of the shop unless you take 12 oranges as well.' What kind of madness is this?

The member for Gellibrand talks about surgeons, for example. All of us, me included, would like to see more women surgeons in Australia, but do you seriously think that the way to get more women into the surgical profession is to get more men as well? That is the absurdity of what the Labor Party are saying. They are saying that we must spend the next decade hand-wringing while fatherless boys get from birth to the end of primary school without ever having had a man in their lives because, apparently, we have to get more women into primary schools as well as more men. What kind of inspiration would that provide to John Cleese? It is the sort of thing that prompts you to go back and have another look at Life of Brian. What kind of nonsense is it? This is well-intentioned but crippling ideology, and our sons and women who will suffer because of this will pay a very high price. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is very hard in this debate not to respond to the complete absurdity of the arguments that the government is putting. We have just heard that scholarships being offered to women to go into teaching are not an appropriate thing, even though I would have thought—in question time the minister gives us a lot of homilies about people who cannot afford to go to university or TAFE or get a further education—that the prime objective of a scholarship that pays for students to do their teaching course is to assist those who are financially disadvantaged. That is actually the purpose of a scholarship. These scholarships are designed in that way. As the minister well knows, the Catholic Education Office already offers large numbers of scholarships, which by chance—or not by chance, because we know that this is a problem—do primarily go to women.

speech.para: To say that requiring an extra number of scholarships to go to women is somehow an outrage, when we know that there are a lot of talented and capable men and women who may go into teaching if they had some financial assistance, and to disparage us in doing that because it does not fit with the sort of initiative that the government is talking about, is a nonsense. I do not want to get stuck in a tit-for-tat debate on this but I want to put on the record that we believe it is important that students who are financially disadvantaged should be able to access support to undertake whatever courses they want. We actually think this is an important issue. It highlights our view that this particular initiative, whether it is changing the Sex Discrimination Act or the offering of scholarships, is not the one that will necessarily resolve this problem.

The human rights commission's initial rejection of the scholarship application was based on the fact that there was no evidence that it was the financial disadvantage of being a student that was stopping men going into teaching; in fact, it was possibly a range of other things, particularly the financial disadvantage they would suffer in the long term by teaching being seriously underpaid. It is those issues of the status of the profession, the pay rates and issues relating to child protection—all of these complex matters—that are putting men off going into teaching.

Scholarships may be one way of dealing with it, but let us not pretend that we are causing some problem by also offering scholarships to women—who may be financially disadvantaged, who may be fantastic teachers, who may be just as entitled to support as men are. The outcome that has been reached between the Catholic Education Office and the human rights commission is actually the opposite of what the minister asserts. It is a sensible way of getting extra men into teaching and of also providing assistance to women who might be able to get into teaching, might want to do it, might make fantastic teachers and might need that financial assistance too. Whatever provocation the minister raises in his next response, I will promise not to rise in this debate again. I think we have traversed all of these issues in great detail.

The opposition do not believe that this legislation is the most effective way of delivering an outcome that we support, and we call on the government to withdraw the bill and talk to us sensibly about the sorts of initiatives that could really deliver an outcome to those boys that the minister talks so passionately about—who are not going to have everything in their lives resolved just by getting men into schools. That will not happen if we do not make sure that we always have quality teachers in schools, if we do not make sure that we support the mix of skills that people need, if we do not make sure that we get the best people by improving their pay and conditions over time—all of those things that a government can have an impact on. I call on the minister to withdraw this bill and allow those discussions to be undertaken, rather than have this diversion of amending the Sex Discrimination Act.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr NELSON
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: —If you think Labor's position through logically, you cannot accept the absurdity—obviously the government does not. Of course scholarships should be available to women. They should be available to people of all genders. But, when you are trying to deal with a specific problem, which is a lack of men in primary schools—as the Western Australian government has done, as the Catholic Education Office is trying to do—you should be able to offer specific male-only scholarships. I say to the Labor Party: for obvious reasons, I will not be a mother. Despite having watched Life of Brian and understanding where Cleese gets a lot of his inspiration from, I am not going to be a mother. That is pretty obvious. But could I plead with the Labor Party, could I plead with the Leader of the Opposition to listen to the mothers of Australia who are terribly distressed about their boys not having fathers or men in their lives.

speech.para: It also ought to be pointed out to the Labor Party that this is the kind of nonsense that we have to put up with in this country. The United Trades and Labour Council in the state of South Australia successfully got an exemption to put women into workplaces to train them to be union officials. I have no trouble with that; that is sensible. They have got a desperate shortage of women union officials. At the University of Melbourne, they offer women-only scholarships for postgraduate engineers. Why? Because we are desperately short of female engineers who have advanced training. I have got no problems with that. I understand the logic of that. The human rights commission said, `Yes, no problems.'

The Victorian government has announced that it will be giving at least half of its legal work to women at the Victorian bar because, apparently, only 18 per cent of lawyers in the state of Victoria are women—coincide-entally, the same percentage of men who are training to be primary teachers. No-one is up in arms about that. Some of my colleagues will not agree with that, but at a personal level I think, `Okay, if that's what we've got to do to give women a better break in the legal profession, I'll have a go at that.' But what we are trying to do here is to bring qualities that are specific to the male gender to primary school classrooms in order to inform the personal development of our sons and our daughters, particularly those who come from fatherless families.

The Catholic Education Office might have sufficiently deep pockets to engage lawyers and so on to deal with the human rights commission and all this sort of business, but if you are running a small Christian school, a Montessori school or an Aboriginal community school, you have not got the resources to do that. You cannot do that. You cannot be fearful that every time you try to apply a bit of commonsense you have got to run a cake stall, a raffle and all sorts of fundraising to employ an army of lawyers to go through this nonsense. This bill is sensible. The amendment is clearly defined as applying to teacher education. Entry into the education profession is, and will be, still entirely merit based.

I ask the well-intentioned but misplaced ideologues on the other side: say, for example, that only eight per cent of people on boards in Australia are women—which is the situation at the moment; would we then say, `Right. The way we are going to deal with that is that we are now going to attract more women and we are going to attract more men'? John Cleese and the people in Life of Brian would say, `Yes, that's terrific. Good on you, Stan. That's what we're going to do.' The Labor Party's position here is nonsense, and it is irreconcilable with the attitudes and views of many on the Labor backbench—

talk.start.para: —with which you, in particular, would be only too familiar.

speech.para: Question put:

motion.para: That the bill be agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Dr NELSON (Bradfield—Minister for Education, Science and Training) (10.21 a.m.)—by leave—I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

subdebate.1.para: Question agreed to.
Bill read a third time.

debateinfo.title: TRADE PRACTICES AMENDMENT (PERSONAL INJURIES AND DEATH) BILL (NO. 2) 2004

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 19 March, on motion by Mr Ross Cameron:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Trade Practices Amendment (Personal Injuries and Death) Bill (No. 2) 2004 provides an opportunity to set out Labor's position on the reforms necessary to address soaring insurance costs, particularly in relation to public liability. Over the last two years there has been widespread public concern about rising public liability premiums and the threat they pose to the operation of many small businesses and community activities. In a bid to address these concerns, the states and territories embarked on a range of reforms to their negligence laws to reduce claim costs and bring damages into line with community standards.

speech.para: Labor has consistently stressed the need for Commonwealth action to support the efforts of the state and territory governments to reduce public liability premiums. Labor supported amendments to taxation laws to facilitate structured settlements which reduce costs to insurers. Labor supported amendments to the Trade Practices Act to allow people who engage in high-risk recreational activities to waive their right to sue. Labor also supported legislation to remove the personal liability of volunteers performing work for the Commonwealth.

Unlike the government, Labor tried to ensure that the benefits of tort reform were passed on to consumers. The latest ACCC price-monitoring report shows that insurers are again making profits on public liability business. While claims costs are falling, premiums are continuing to rise. Claims costs for personal injury and death fell by 14 per cent in the first six months of 2003. Public liability premiums rose by four per cent over the same period. In September 2002 Labor introduced legislation to enable the ACCC to ensure that cost savings generated by the state tort law reforms were passed on to consumers in the form of lower premiums. But the government refused to debate the bill. Labor believes the government should ensure that consumers, not just the insurance companies, benefit from tort reform.

I now turn to the detail of the bill we are debating today. This bill is intended to address concern that the state and territory reforms will be undermined by forum shopping—that is, that plaintiffs will seek to avoid the restrictions imposed under the state tort reforms by bringing actions under the Trade Practices Act. This is possible because, in theory, the same conduct may form the basis of action in tort for negligence as well as under the provisions of the Trade Practices Act for misleading and deceptive conduct, unconscionable conduct or defective products.

The bill inserts a new part VIB into the Trade Practices Act to deal with those parts of the act which could be used as a basis of action for damages for personal injury. These provisions include part IVA, which prohibits unconscionable conduct, and part VA, which establishes standards in relation to defective goods. Part VIB introduces a range of restrictions and limitations on the award of damages for personal injury for breach of the TPA. It provides that, as a general rule, proceedings must be instituted within three years of discovering an injury. Damages for pain and suffering will be capped at $250,000, and this amount will be indexed by the consumer price index. The bill inserts a threshold to avoid the proliferation of small claims, which have been driving much of the increase in total claims costs. Damages will not be awarded if the court assesses that the non-economic loss incurred by the plaintiff is less than 15 per cent of the most extreme case. The bill also caps damages for loss of earning capacity at twice the level of average weekly earnings. Another major component of claims costs is damages awarded for gratuitous attendant care services, which are defined in the bill as:

quote.para: ... services that one person provides to another person:

speech.para: (a) that:
(i) are of a domestic nature; or
(ii) relate to nursing; or
(iii) aim to alleviate the consequences of a personal injury; and
(b) for which the other person has not paid or is not liable to pay.

The bill imposes caps and thresholds on the award of damages for these services. In order for damages to be paid, the services must have been provided, or are to be provided, for at least six hours per week over six months. Damages for payment of the services are capped at average weekly earnings. The new part VIB also proposes that a discount rate of five per cent apply to future economic loss in determining the present value of lump sum payments. The bill also prohibits the award of exemplary or aggravated damages. The new part VIB is broadly consistent with the approach applied by the states and territories in their negligence reforms. Because in some respects it is tougher than previous provisions applying under state laws, it will deter forum shopping. Labor supports the damages regime proposed by the bill.

The House should note that the government's approach in this bill is in stark contrast to the approach it adopted in relation to the first tranche of trade practices reform. In the Trade Practices Amendment (Personal Injuries and Death) Bill 2003 the government sought to remove the ability of consumers and the ACCC to recover damages for personal injury and death sustained as a result of conduct which breaches the unfair practices provisions in division 1 of part V of the Trade Practices Act. The key provision in part V is section 52, which prohibits corporations from engaging in misleading and deceptive conduct.

Following a Senate inquiry, Labor moved amendments to the bill consistent with a proposal which had been made by the ACCC. The Senate supported these amendments, which picked up state and territory caps and thresholds on damages to ensure that a plaintiff could not receive a higher judgment under the Trade Practices Act than if they sued for negligence under state law. The government refused to accept these amendments. As a consequence, damages for personal injury under division 1 of part V remain uncapped and are not subject to any of the thresholds that apply under state civil liability laws, so the potential for forum shopping remains.

I would like to briefly discuss some of the reasons advanced by the government for opposing Labor's amendments. The government's position is that there should be no liability under section 52 for personal injury and death, because section 52 is a no-fault provision. By that the government means there is no requirement to prove that a person acted negligently or dishonestly in order for liability to arise under section 52.

The government's position on related issues is inconsistent. Soon the House will debate the Treasury Legislation Amendment (Professional Standards) Bill 2003. This bill seeks to support state laws which cap the liability of professionals. Once again, the government argues that it is necessary to amend the misleading and deceptive conduct provisions of the TPA to support the state reforms. However, in the professional standards bill, damages under the TPA for misleading and deceptive conduct are capped to an amount set by state law. The right to bring an action is not abolished. The government's preferred approach therefore gives rise to the following anomaly: where a consumer loses thousands of dollars as a result of misleading and deceptive conduct by their accountant they will be entitled to compensation under the Trade Practices Act; in contrast, when a company's misleading and deceptive conduct causes personal injury or death, consumers will not have a remedy under the Trade Practices Act. The government may wish to explain the inconsistent treatment it proposes in relation to these two types of events under the no-fault provisions.

Under section 74D of part VA, consumers have a right to bring an action for damages where goods are not of merchantable quality. This is also a no-fault provision. A consumer does not have to show that the manufacturer of the goods knew, or should have known, that they were flawed. In this bill the government accepts that a breach of section 74D can be a basis of action for damages where the breach resulted in personal injury. Again the government may wish to explain the difference between its proposed treatment of the no-fault provisions under section 74D and section 52. So far the government's only explanation is that the parliament never intended section 52 to cover personal injury damages. However, in the 12 months since the Trade Practices Amendment (Personal Injuries and Death) Bill 2003 was introduced, the government has produced no evidence to support this assertion. That assertion is contradicted by the presence of section 4K, which makes clear reference to loss or damage in the act, including by injury.

In making its case to abolish the rights of consumers to seek personal injury damages under section 52, the government has repeatedly argued that doctors' exposure to the Trade Practices Act is driving up medical indemnity premiums. However, there is no evidence that liability under the TPA is a major contributor to medical indemnity claims costs. The report of the Medical Indemnity Policy Review Panel to the Prime Minister last December did not make one reference to liability under the TPA. Senator Coonan said that a doctor who recommends that a patient undergo an operation to have a growth removed on the basis that it could be malignant may be found to have misled the patient if it were later discovered that the growth was benign and the operation unnecessary. However, the case law on section 52 suggests this is not so. The case law indicates that a prediction or opinion is not misleading or deceptive merely because it does not come to pass or is incorrect. An opinion will breach section 52 if the person making it knew it to be false and misleading or was reckless. If a doctor can show that he or she acted reasonably, he or she will not be held liable. That is what the case law says. The minister should exercise more caution when commenting on the effects of a provision that has been in force for 30 years.

Labor's efforts to maintain broad application of section 52 are supported by the ACCC. In its submission to the Ipp review of the law of negligence, the ACCC argued that it would be both economically inefficient and morally unjustifiable to expose consumers to greater risk and relieve suppliers of their existing obligation to fully inform consumers of those risks. Last December the Deputy Chair of the ACCC, Louise Sylvan, said that `serious harm would flow from any proposal that narrowed the scope of provisions prohibiting misleading and deceptive conduct'. The argument that it was unfair to impose liability on companies because section 52 is a no-fault provision was also rejected by the commission. ACCC commissioner Jennifer McNeill, in giving evidence before the Senate Economics Legislation Committee, said:

quote.para: In a situation where a business misleads or deceives a consumer and the consumer suffers damage—in this case, personal injury—as a result, the commission thinks that, as a matter of principle, they should be held accountable and liable for that damage, irrespective of intention. In part, that is because it is much more within the control of the business involved whether and how the representations are made; it is not within the control of the consumer whether and how the representations are made.

speech.para: Last year the Senate Economics Legislation Committee heard evidence of several plausible scenarios where the removal of the right to bring an action under part V, division 1 could result in consumers being left without a remedy. The examples included cases where defendants had destroyed crucial evidence. Section 52 of the Trade Practices Act serves as a safety net in these rare cases. More broadly, witnesses emphasised the contribution made by the Trade Practices Act in creating a culture of care in the business community.

While Labor supports the continued application of section 52 to personal injury cases, we believe that action is required to support the state and territory reforms. In an effort to achieve this, my colleague Senator Conroy wrote to Minister Coonan earlier this month, suggesting a solution to the current impasse. Labor proposed to the government that, in order to ensure a consistent approach applies to all cases where personal injury results from a breach of the Trade Practices Act, this bill should be amended to ensure that the constraints on damages and limitation periods imposed by this bill should also apply to actions brought under division 1 of part V. This would only require a simple amendment to proposed section 87E of the bill. Unfortunately, the minister rejected the proposal. The opposition is disappointed by the minister's response. The only conclusion the community can draw from it is that the government is not interested in achieving any workable compromise. Labor supports the objective of this bill to restrict the damages available under the Trade Practices Act in order to deter forum shopping. This can be done while preserving the application of fundamental consumer protection provisions of the act. I urge the government to reconsider the merit of applying the scheme contained in the Trade Practices Amendment (Personal Injuries and Death) Bill (No. 2) 2004 to the other provisions of the Trade Practices Act that can be used as a basis for action for personal injury.

talk.start.para: —In a case that has become known as a seminal decision on the Trade Practices Act and its operation, Brown and the Jam Factory Pty Ltd, reported in the Federal Law Reports in 1981 at page 340, the Federal Court, which has over time had primary responsibility for the administration of this statute, in the Full Court, in relation to the primary provision in division 1 of part V of the statute currently under consideration in the amendments proposed in the Trade Practices Amendment (Personal Injuries and Death) Bill (No. 2) 2004, which is currently before the House, said:

quote.para: Section 52 is a comprehensive provision of wide import, which does not adopt the language of any common law cause of action. It does not purport to create liability at all; rather, it establishes a norm of conduct ...

speech.para: At the heart of the discussion in relation to the expedient provisions that are currently before the House in terms of amendments and counterproposals from the opposition is the question as to whether or not the provisions of part V, division 1 should be amended to undermine that basic standard. My basic point in relation to that question is that the amendments before the House do not; rather they address a different question—that is, whether or not the Trade Practices Act in its current form has utility in the context of the insurance crisis that this country has faced over the last few years.

There are two issues that struck me as being important in the context of the issue of principle. The first is whether the provisions before the House might in some way undermine the general standard that the Trade Practices Act sets out in relation to consumer provisions. I suggest that they do not, because the mere fact that there may be some curtailment on recovery of damages does not necessarily undermine the general principle or standard for which the act provides.

The second criticism, which is inherent in some aspects of the comments of the member for Kingston's observations, is that different standards in place for different forms of loss under the Trade Practices Act—for example, economic loss versus loss for personal injury or death—would arise from the amendments brought by the government. At the end of the day, that does not really bite as a criticism, because the legislation before the House is seeking to limit the types of recoverability so as to retain a general regime such as found in part V, division 1.

The specific terms of part V, division 1 deserve some consideration before going to the terms of the amendments and giving some detailed consideration to those. Division 1 contains key consumer protection measures, the most commonly used ones being those that deal with misleading and deceptive conduct—and I have already referred to section 52—and false and misleading representations in section 53. There are other provisions in part V, division 1 of the act, including provisions dealing with bait advertising, harassment and coercion and pyramid selling, which are affected by these amendments.

Provisions in part V, division 1, where breached, give rise to a right to recover damages for any loss that has been suffered as a result of a contravention. In addition, consumers can seek injunctive relief, punitive orders—and, indeed, non-punitive orders—and remedial orders. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission can take legal action on behalf of a person who has suffered loss, as can individuals claiming such loss where provisions have been breached. It is even possible for criminal proceedings to be brought against persons who have breached any one of the requirements, other than section 52, which does not give rise to a criminal offence. It is important that the Commonwealth takes a lead in these matters—as it did as a result of the Premiers Conference, which was referred to in the minister's second reading speech. This legislation is replicated by all states and territories in their own consumer protection legislation.

The proposed amendments are a second tranche of amendments supporting the reforms that have previously been brought before this place.
