speech.para: All industry participants, including workers, will benefit from working in an environment in which laws are respected and obligations are complied with. No-one is above the law. Laws must apply to all citizens whether they be union officials, employers or workers.
Reform of the building and construction industry is something the Australian government cannot and will not ignore.

The government has moved swiftly to implement the royal commission's recommendations. In recognising the real need for reform this government, following the royal commission recommendations, introduced specific legislation aimed at reforming the building and construction industry.

This legislation was passed in this House on 4 December last year, but is now stalled. It is the subject of a Senate references committee inquiry consisting of five Labor senators who have all been given their orders by Labor's shadow cabinet, which has already resolved not to implement any of the royal commission recommendations. The double standards are breathtaking.

This government, however, will not stand still on reform. This government is committed to genuine cultural and structural reform that this industry so desperately needs. Federal and state governments from both sides of the political fence have made attempts in the past to reform the industry, but all have failed. This government will not repeat the same mistakes. Having separate industry specific legislation is the key to bringing about the changes long overdue in this unique industry.

The industry does want change but is ill-equipped to initiate and deliver it on its own. The government will not allow the tactics of delay and misinformation by the Labor Party and its union bosses to distract us from the need to bring the much needed change.

The task force is one such way to give the industry a helping hand. Some people have the view that as the task force is titled `interim' there is no need to take it seriously—that it will go away in the same way as other attempts to reform this industry have in the past.

So that there is no misunderstanding, no confusion, no mixed signals, so that it is clear to all that the government is serious about reform, the interim task force will now be established as the `Building Industry Taskforce'. It will continue to operate until the Building and Construction Industry Improvement Bill (and the establishment of the ABCC) is passed by this parliament.

The task force with a strong contingent of inspectors will continue to make its presence felt in the building industry. The task force will use all of its powers to uphold the law. The task force which will continue to shine a light on the dark side of this industry is another step toward achieving lasting and long overdue reform in this industry.

If the Labor Party continues to delay the passage of the bill, the government will also pursue the use of alternative arrangements to establish the federal safety commissioner to address the significant occupational health and safety issues within the industry. For too long safety matters in this industry have not been taken seriously with bogus claims being made by unions to force illegal industrial action on employers. Safety is a serious issue and this government is serious about improving safety outcomes. We will do this by requiring best practice on Australian government construction sites.

This government is also concerned with evidence that suggests employee entitlements are being neglected by cowboy employers. Employers are and must be legally responsible for their employees' entitlements. Employees need to be assured that if they go to work these entitlements will be paid to them.

To deal with rogue employers who do not meet their obligations, the Office of Workplace Services will target the building and construction industry firstly in Victoria, New South Wales and Western Australia with education and compliance programs to ensure employers meet their and employees get their legal obligations.

This is in addition to action already taken by this government, across all industries, to protect employee entitlements. This government has been the first to seriously address the issue of employee entitlements lost on insolvency. To date more than $168 million has been paid to over 29,000 employees under this government's GEER scheme.

In addition, I will be writing to small and medium size businesses to ensure they are aware of assistance available to them on any workplace issues, wages and conditions, health and safety, taxation or training.
This industry is in desperate need of reform. The government is doing and will continue to do its bit to clean up this industry.
The Labor Party do not want to acknowledge the problems that exist within this industry. Their hands are tied by the union bosses.
It is not a very hard choice for this government—a choice between continued unlawful behaviour costing all Australians billions of dollars and a commitment to lasting reform.
This government has made its choice.
We say to the Labor Party: stop allowing this unlawful behaviour to continue. The challenge for the Labor Party is to start acting in the interest of all Australians and pass the BCII Bill.

One year ago the royal commission prepared case studies from evidence heard of unlawful and inappropriate behaviour in each state and territory. Many were cases where serious breaches of the law had been identified.
One year ago the Attorney-General's Department referred these matters to relevant state and territory governments for investigation and swift and appropriate action.
It is a matter of grave concern that, one year on, the state and territory investigations on these matters have still not provided a finalised outcome.
Why have state and territory governments failed to act upon these referrals when they committed to do so?
I am urging the state and territory governments to do what they said they would and finalise these matters as it is in the best interests of good government to do so.

I will be writing to all relevant state and territory ministers and asking them to advise the Australian government and the Australian people why they still have not done anything about the matters referred to them.
I would like to end today by quoting someone who some 14 years ago recognised that this industry desperately needed reform. He said:

quote.para: Friends, this industry is going to have to bite the bullet at last. If this country wants to be efficient and productive, everybody has to undergo the reform process—and most especially an industry which has such pressuring and demonstrable need for it. So reform in the construction industry starts now ... Let me make it clear that the Government is committed to real microeconomic reform in the industry. The aim of reform is to produce real savings in productivity and efficiency to encourage greater investment in the industry. It entails taking on issues long regarded as too hard but who settlement is crucial to the performance of the industry. By this I mean issues as poor employment relationships, restrictive work practices, lost time, the adversarial approach to industrial relations in the industry ...

speech.para: This is not a statement from a coalition minister. This is a statement from Senator Peter Cook, the Minister for Industrial Relations in 1990. If only he and the Labor Party had still had the moral courage to stand by this commitment.
Unlike the Labor Party, this government will not resile from the need to ensure that the rule of law must apply in this industry as it does everywhere else.
I present a copy of my ministerial statement and the following paper:

para.inline: Upholding the law—one year on: findings of the interim building industry taskforce

speech.para: I move:

motion.para: That the House take note of the papers.

speech.para: Miss JACKIE KELLY (Lindsay—Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister) (3.44 p.m.)—by leave—I move:

motion.para: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent Mr Emerson speaking for a period not exceeding 20 minutes.

speech.para: Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: —The government's agenda in the building industry is not about jobs or productivity or supposed lawlessness. The government's agenda in the building industry has its genesis in the political strife it found itself in following its defeat in the Ryan by-election in early 2001. It needed a union-busting agenda as a diversion from its political woes. This agenda is about taking away bargaining power from workers in one of Australia's most dangerous, and most productive, industries. It is not about deregulating the industry but about regulating it.

speech.para: Labor acknowledges that employees in the building industry do have a strong bargaining position in their negotiations with employers. In the tough, dangerous industry of commercial construction, unionisation rates are traditionally very high and workers are quick to defend their terms and conditions of employment. Workers in this industry are highly sensitive to health and safety concerns and quick to react if they see themselves or their colleagues at risk of harm. This is totally understandable in an industry where there is, on average, a workplace fatality each and every week, often in terribly careless circumstances. For instance, young Dean McGoldrick and Joel Exner, aged 16 and 17, fell to their deaths while working without proper safety harnesses and equipment. But the tragedies on building sites do not stop with fatalities. Anthony Hampson was working for Joel Exner's employer in October 2001 when he fell from a roofing job. Mr Hampson suffered spinal injuries and was wheelchair bound for six months. With young workers dying and being seriously injured as a result of poor safety practices, is it any wonder that the unions that represent these workers are so resolute in their protection of their members? Is it any wonder that these workers are vigilant in defending their own? But the Prime Minister hates strong unions.

I want to spend a bit of time speaking about true reform. I am not saying that this industry is perfect and that there is no room for improvement—far from it. There are serious issues in this industry that need to be addressed, but most of these were glossed over by the $60 million witch-hunt that the government calls a royal commission. That is why Labor, along with the Democrats and Greens, felt the need for a more balanced investigation into the industry and established a Senate references committee inquiry. This inquiry has already held hearings in Canberra, Sydney, Brisbane, Perth and Adelaide and is proceeding to Darwin and Melbourne in the coming weeks. The inquiry has broad terms of reference to enable it to investigate areas glossed over by the Cole royal commission, including underpayment of employee entitlements, tax evasion, use of sham corporate structures and, of course, health and safety. The inquiry has also questioned whether the government's proposed legislation provides an appropriate way forward for this industry, or, to use the government's own criterion: will weakening the role of building unions make the cost of building a wall in a high-rise building the same as that in a domestic building? For a brighter future, does this industry need new government appointed and directed task forces whose primary role is to police building unions?

I agree with the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations on one thing: the same laws should apply to all industries and all Australians. On that basis, the government should withdraw the so-called Building and Construction Industry Improvement Bill 2003, which provides a separate set of laws for the building and construction industry. The government's 200-page bill, with 30 pages alone on compulsory secret ballots for industrial action, is not the way forward for this industry. It is legislation that was prepared for political purposes and designed to fail. It is complex, conflict-driven legislation based on false assumptions that will not assist the industry or its consumers.

The minister claims that this industry is crippled by lawlessness. Far from being crippled, the industry is booming. In May 1997 there were 575,000 people working in the building industry; in May 2003 there were 737,000—an extra 160,000 jobs in this industry. According to the Productivity Commission, the construction industry is the fourth most productive industry in Australia. The government's claim that commercial construction is 40 per cent less efficient than domestic construction is just wrong. The Senate inquiry has heard evidence from many witnesses on why there are significant cost differentials between commercial and domestic construction—none of these had anything to do with union activity or industrial relations. Factors cited include different engineering and material standards, different safety standards—given that high-rise buildings are more dangerous to work on—and different cabling and scaffolding requirements. These factors were perhaps best summarised by Mr Greg Packer of the Walter Construction Group in the Brisbane hearing:

quote.para: ... it is reasonably hard to get the right picture for comparison between the domestic sector and the commercial sector.

speech.para: Nevertheless, the minister is yet again using this false comparison to justify this expensive union-busting exercise. We are dealing here with a one-sided regulator. The Queensland Master Builders Association told the Senate inquiry what it perceived to be the key issues facing this industry, one of which was the need for streamlined processes for the recovery of unpaid employee entitlements.

This is one of the most glaring omissions in the government's plan for this industry. The underpayment or nonpayment of employee entitlements will not be assisted by the government's proposed legislation or by its permanent building task force. We know this not only from the bill but also from the track record of the existing interim building industry task force. The interim task force was established in September 2002. Since then it has focused almost entirely on union activities and has not even attempted to take a balanced approach to investigating breaches of law in this industry. The charter of the task force provides:

quote.para: The Taskforce has prime responsibility for the following matters in respect to the building and construction industry:

speech.para: alleged breaches of awards and agreements.

A reasonable person would assume that this meant that the task force would investigate all noncompliance with terms and conditions of awards and agreements, such as underpayment of entitlements to employees, but that is not how the task force sees its own duties. At the most recent Senate estimates hearings in February 2003, Senator Wong questioned the director of the task force, Nigel Hadgkiss, on this very issue. She said:

quote.para: I understand none of the cases that you currently have before the courts relate to any nonpayment of any employee entitlement. Is that right?
Mr Hadgkiss—That is my recollection.
Senator WONG—You say in this answer that it is not part of your remit to investigate instances of underpayments. Is that right?
Mr Hadgkiss—That is correct.

speech.para: So much for investigating underpayment of employee entitlements. So much for assurances from the minister that that is what this permanent task force would do. Mr Hadgkiss's frank evidence confirms what we already knew: the government has spent millions of dollars on the royal commission and the interim task force, acting as a private police force and legal representative for employers in the building industry. This is unashamedly biased, unashamedly one-sided—and now permanent as well.

The work of the task force will be continued with the bodies outlined in today's statement—the Australian Building and Construction Commission and the Federal Safety Commission. There is no doubt that these new agencies would only be there to help employers. The health and safety commission would not be about health and safety; it would be about keeping unions out of health and safety issues and about policing disputes about health and safety. This is the approach taken to health and safety by the interim task force, as was also admitted by Mr Hadgkiss at the February estimates hearing. Mr Hadgkiss admitted that his officers would investigate health and safety matters only if they suspected that a health and safety dispute was not genuinely about health and safety. Anything else would not be their problem.

Let us discuss the matter of lawlessness. This year the building task force had an annual budget of $6.8 million. Last year it was $5.9 million. That is a total so far of $12.7 million. Yet with almost $13 million the task force has only managed to carry out 400 investigations, resulting in only 13 prosecutions in the 18 months since it was established. Of those 13 prosecutions, only five are characterised as `successful'. One of these prosecutions was brought to the attention of the Senate inquiry by Doug Cameron, Secretary of the AMWU. It involved a phoenix company—one which shut down operations under one name and restarted under another, slightly different name. The task force was not concerned to check if any payments or obligations were avoided by this sham corporate structure. Its investigations instead centred on a notice for protected industrial action by the AMWU, which used the previous company name.

When asked about this matter, again at the February estimates hearing, Mr Hadgkiss said the matter was pursued because of the task force's `zero tolerance' policy. On 24 February 2004, New South Wales Chief Industrial Magistrate George Miller found that the union's breach could be described as `an inadvertent error' and fined the union $2,000. Unfortunately, as I have already pointed out, the task force's zero tolerance policy seems to apply only in respect of union related breaches of laws and obligations. Even when prosecutions are brought against employers they are about issues such as the payment of strike pay, as in the case finalised against Baulderstone Hornibrook last night and referred to in the minister's statement today. The task force will investigate and prosecute employers for paying employees during periods of industrial action but will not investigate and prosecute employers who fail to pay employees.

The task force has spent $13 million and brought just 13 prosecutions. Of the five finalised cases, one was about a technical paperwork breach and another was about a company deciding to pay its employees while they took industrial action. This is hardly evidence of rampant lawlessness. It is also an astonishing amount of taxpayers' money spent for so few cases. Compare this to the Commonwealth Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions. Its latest annual report tells us that in 2002-03 it spent $61.3 million, about five times the amount spent by the task force so far. For this amount of money the DPP launched 4,726 prosecutions, of which 4,608 resulted in convictions. I understand that there are some differences between the way these two bodies function, but this is an astronomical difference in getting results from the use of taxpayers' money.

Let us talk about a way forward. A number of submissions to the Senate inquiry have spoken about the need for cultural change in this industry and the need for greater cooperation. Labor supports this position but, sadly, today's government statement does nothing to progress it. The value of the trust model was highlighted in the construction of the Sydney Olympics. That great project was delivered on time and under budget, under a memorandum of understanding agreed by all the relevant parties. There was one fatality on that site—which is one too many—but there was a pretty good health and safety record through the trust model, the cooperative approach.

The need for trust was most acutely highlighted by Dr John Buchanan, a pre-eminent industrial relations researcher from the University of Sydney. When asked by Senator Cook at the Sydney hearing of the inquiry about trust in the industry, Dr Buchanan replied:

motion.para: That is the essence of the problem here. It seems to me that that is the better place to start. If you are thinking about how you get through the problems in the construction industry, do you send in the Scuds and the Exocets or do you think a little more laterally and ask, `If we want an industry that is high trust in 10 years time, what do we have to do?' You get a completely different set of answers if you ask that question.

speech.para: I agree with Dr Buchanan: we need to consider better ways forward. But trying to beat one party—unions—into submission is not a way towards trust and cooperation. Setting up a new, powerful, minister directed police force is not the way towards trust and cooperation. We need instead to investigate truly cooperative mechanisms that could be used to establish an environment of trust.

Cooperative mechanisms exist and have successfully existed in various states in this and other industries. The state governments have endorsed a 10-point plan for the building industry, which includes introducing good faith bargaining provisions and giving the Industrial Relations Commission the power to settle intractable disputes. This is a far more constructive approach than that proposed by the federal government. We strongly support the need for good faith bargaining provisions and we have introduced legislation to insert such provisions into the Workplace Relations Act. But Labor does not support the establishment of private police forces or spending millions of dollars of taxpayers' money pursuing technical breaches of paperwork by unions. The government's whole approach to the building industry represents a terrible waste of money and a missed opportunity to move the industry towards a more positive future.

The minister quoted Senator Cook at the end of his statement. That is ironic. Senator Cook's statement was made in the lead-up to the establishment of the Construction Industry Development Agency, a cooperative body of exactly the type that might be useful in restoring trust in this industry. Of course, the minister conveniently failed to mention that. And what did the Howard government do when it came to office? It abolished this agency. It abolished the cooperative approach and instead has pursued a confrontationist approach. It is the government which is being the industrial dinosaur here, playing its old game of conflict and division. Labor will not be part of this game. Instead, we will be looking for cooperative solutions to the issues that challenge the building industry.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ross Cameron) adjourned.

debate.para: The following bill was returned from the Senate without amendment or request:

para.inline: Privacy Amendment Bill 2004

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—The Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Werriwa proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

quote.para: The Howard Government's mismanagement of Australia's national security.

interjection.para: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —This is a government in disarray over national security; a government that has compromised the independence and role of the Australian Federal Police; a government that is always putting the Liberal Party's political interests ahead of our national security interests; a government that is defying the obvious—that, while Australia was a target at the time of September 11, the war in Iraq has made things worse; a government that sent young Australians to war in Iraq for a purpose that was not true. As Senator Hill said on Tuesday, at least for an hour or two, Iraq has no weapons of mass destruction. It is a government that has diverted effort and resources away from targeting the terrorists and put them into Iraq, and now it is a government that does not know how to get our troops out of Iraq. It was easy to race in but now it is a government that does not know how to get out—a government with no exit strategy, no way of getting the troops home for the defence of Australia. It is a government that, in this regard, is in total confusion and total disarray.

speech.para: In May of last year in New York the Prime Minister was asked about the commitment of troops in Iraq. The journalist asked `Do you see it as months or years'? And the Prime Minister replied `Well, I certainly don't see it as years', implying that he saw it as a matter of months. Then in the parliament yesterday he was asked the clear question by the member for Griffith about the extent of Australia's ADF deployment, whether it should be months rather than years, and the Prime Minister's answer:

quote.para: I am very happy to say it should not be years ...

speech.para: There was the Prime Minister defining the government's own commitment. Given the fact that Australia has had a deployment in Iraq for over 12 months already, for the Prime Minister to honour that commitment of saying it should not be years, he is obliged to withdraw our troops from Iraq by the end of 2004 or the beginning of 2005. But in the same answer he says he is not in favour of a time line, implying that he believes in an open-ended commitment to our troops in Iraq. So, in the same parliamentary answer, within the space of a few minutes, the Prime Minister actually has two positions: one a position of saying it should not be for years, implying that the troops should be out at the end of 2004 or the beginning of 2005, and then a position of saying there should be an indefinite commitment—a government that is totally confused on the key question of national security. The poor chap is just spinning around, totally confused and in total disarray about what should happen to the Australian commitment in Iraq.

Labor's position has always been clear and principled. We want our troops back as soon as possible after Australia has discharged its international responsibility. It is of course logical and right to use the change of sovereignty, the new Iraqi government, as the turning point. That is why a Labor government elected, say, in September will ensure, and certainly has the intention of, having our troops home by Christmas. That is the Labor position. Our intention is to have our troops home by Christmas if a Labor government is elected in September. This builds on the announcement made by the member for Griffith, the shadow minister for foreign affairs, from Baghdad, on 14 November last year. This is what he said:

quote.para: The early establishment of an interim Iraqi government would also provide Australia with an appropriate exit strategy from its current formal responsibilities as an Occupying Power under the Fourth Geneva Convention.
At present, we do not have such an exit strategy.

speech.para: Australia does now. Australia does have such a strategy. It is Labor's strategy of having our troops back by Christmas. What we are doing is holding the government to their original position when they said `months, not years', when the Prime Minister said he did not believe in a commitment that ran into years, that would not go beyond two years—a commitment that would have our troops back by Christmas. All this chopping and changing by the Prime Minister and the government is plain bad for the defence of Australia. It is not good policy to be chopping and changing so comprehensively on such a key issue of national interest and national security.

As for all these coalition MPs accusing me of being on the side of al-Qaeda, we know that slur; we have heard it before. It is the same thing that the Minister for Foreign Affairs said about the Police Commissioner, Mick Keelty. He said that the Police Commissioner was talking in a way that associated him with al-Qaeda propaganda. It is their standard slur. When someone does not agree with them, they do not argue the point in the national interest but put the slur out about al-Qaeda. I do not care too much what they say about me; it washes over me totally.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs pipes up. I think he has a ladder in his stockings he is squirming there so much, but I know one thing: it sure ain't the ladder of opportunity running up his leg. He can say these things about me—he has the member for Parramatta next to him—it does not worry me in the slightest; it washes over me. The thing I get worked up about is when they slur and slander a good man like Mick Keelty. That is when I get worked up. I am willing to defend him against the Minister for Foreign Affairs and I will defend him against this government's intimidation of his position and the way in which he was slurred by the members opposite. If they want to do something about al-Qaeda other than issue slurs at the doorstops of Parliament House, they should recognise that diverting resources from the real task of attacking al-Qaeda, the real task of targeting the terrorists, diverting resources into Iraq, has not produced the best result. If all the effort, time and resources that have gone into the war in Iraq actually went into targeting the terrorists, then the world would be a safer place today; the world would be a better place.

speech.para: We found out in question time today that, in terms of one of the front-line engagements against the terrorists in Afghanistan, this government have one troop, one soldier. They are waging a one-man war against terrorism in Afghanistan. So with all the resources, time and effort that has gone into Iraq, on that real front line, an active front line, against terror in Afghanistan they have actually got one person—a one-man war against terror. It is the misallocation of resources that this government should be ashamed of.

In terms of our commitment to bringing the troops back by Christmas, we are interested in and committed to the defence of Australia—the defence of Australia always, not the misallocation of resources. There is a public concern in this country that follows the war in Iraq. The government themselves have said that Australia's commitments around the globe are quite stretched. We put the defence of Australia first. Putting the defence and security of Australia first has always been the Labor way and it always will be in the future.

What we see from this government is policy failing after policy failing. But they never admit it; they always say it is a matter of context. So when Mick Keelty speaks the truth that terrorist activity is linked to participation in Iraq—a statement of truth—the government make him go out and say, `No; it's out of context,' and make a clarifying statement drafted under the direct supervision of the Prime Minister. When Senator Hill says that there are no weapons of mass destruction in Iraq—an outbreak of truth—a couple of hours later, there is another clarifying statement saying that he has been quoted out of context. What was the context of Senator Hill's remarks on Tuesday? He said:

quote.para: We went to war in Iraq to support the Security Council which had to be assured that Saddam Hussein had got rid of his weapons of mass destruction. Now we are confident that there are no weapons of mass destruction and there is no dictator that will use them against his own people or his neighbours.

speech.para: What `out of context' could there possibly have been? The context was crystal clear. It was as plain as the nose on the face of the government members opposite. The context was absolutely clear: `Now we are confident that there are no weapons of mass destruction.'

Then there was the shameful comment by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, trying to associate Mick Keelty with al-Qaeda propaganda. Again he says he was quoted out of context, but again the context is totally clear. The Minister for Foreign Affairs said:

quote.para: I think he was just expressing a view which reflects a lot of the propaganda we are getting from al-Qaeda.

speech.para: A shocking thing to say—and something for which he should have apologised publicly in this House of Representatives.

If they say it is a government out of context, we know the truth: it is a government out of time. It is a government that is in an absolute shambles when it comes to the good national security policy of this country. Yet at the end of these debates, at the end of the disarray on national security, the Tories have the hide to say, `Trust us on national security; we're the only ones who can handle it.' Where in Australian history was that proposition ever proven or valid? Not prior to World War II, when the Tories left this country underprepared; not during the folly of Vietnam; not in the misallocation of resources and the difficulties caused by the war in Iraq; and not after the Keelty affair this week. The Tories have a shocking record on national security. It is only ever Labor that gets it right in the defence of Australia, in the best national interest for keeping our people safe and sound against threats.

So it is time for the Australian people once more to look to Labor—to look to the future and to look to Labor. We have no time tunnel we can go down to undo the government's mistakes, but we have a positive agenda for this nation's national security. Our first priority is to target the terrorists themselves and to break up their networks—not repeat the mistakes of Iraq; not fight a war for the wrong core purpose; not divert resources from finding and destroying the terrorists. What we need is the real strength of breaking up their networks and targeting them—having a stronger commitment to targeting the terrorists, not waging wars against nation states for the wrong purpose. We need a lot better than the one-man war in Afghanistan.

Our second priority is to abandon the doctrine of pre-emption. It did not work in Iraq, because there was nothing to pre-empt. It was a failure of intelligence and government decision making. If this government are so competent on national security, why do we have a major inquiry under way into the failings of pre-war intelligence for Iraq? If they are so competent, why do we have this major inquiry under way proving the mistakes that were made in intelligence and government decision making prior to the commitment?

Our third strategy on the Labor side is to build up Australia's self-reliance. We support the American alliance absolutely. We founded it under John Curtin during World War II, and Labor is proud of its founding work and long-term support for the American alliance. But we also believe in self-reliance for Australia within the terms of that alliance. We want to be an equal partner with the United States, not be a deputy sheriff. You will never hear me describing Australia as a deputy sheriff. I am too proud of this country and too proud of what Labor governments have achieved in the past to undersell and underestimate the contribution we can make. Always Australia's self-reliance and an equal partnership with the United States, and never to neglect the home front. Always the defence of Australia first and foremost, not expeditionary forces. Always the defence of Australia in terms of strategic planning for our national defence.

Our fourth strategy is to establish a department of homeland security—an integrated, coordinated model; a one-stop shop where the states and territories can interact with not a dozen federal agencies but one federal government department to get it right—along the lines of the United States model. This is particularly vital for addressing threats to our transport system. We need the strongest possible federal, state and territory cooperation to make this country safe and sound for the future. We urgently need a department of homeland security.

Our fifth strategy is to upgrade our airport and port security. I have visited regional airports in Australia with 70,000 to 80,000 passenger movements per annum and no screening devices for passengers or luggage. We see it at Burnie and in other parts of Tasmania in the electorate of Braddon—no screening devices. Tens of thousands of passengers going through and there are no screening devices for the passengers or their luggage. We have to build up our regional airport security.

So too we have to build up our port security. What has been the government's response? Two and half years after September 11, the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, Mr Anderson, announced a security review on the weekend. That is all this government is good for—reviewing things 2½ years after the event. Two and a half years after the alert was sounded, the government can produce nothing more substantial than a review. This alarming statistic remains with us today: almost a third of the crew aboard visiting foreign cargo ships entering Australia do so without facing passport checks. So a third of the foreign crews on these boats visiting Australia do not have to face passport checks. We need more than a review; we need action. We need government action to build up our port security as we also build up our regional airport security around Australia.

When it comes to national security, you cannot trust the Howard government. They are always playing politics, always looking for the spin and the control and the opportunity to manipulate information—not for the public interest, not for honest statements that the Australian people can consume and understand, but for narrow political purposes. They are always putting their narrow political interests ahead of our national interests. It is time for the government to go. The government are spinning around confused. Less than two years after the engagement in Iraq they still do not know what they are going to do with the withdrawal of our troops. The government are confused about weapons of mass destruction in Iraq—Senator Hill says one thing in the morning and something else in the late morning. The government have vilified and tried to diminish the role of a great Australian in Mick Keelty. The government have gone bad on the doctrine of pre-emption. The government should go, and it should hand over to a Labor administration. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The first point I would like to make is that I have noticed over the years that the Leader of the Opposition, the member for Werriwa, has made these points about coalition governments in the lead-up to World War II. Let it be put on the record that in 1938 the Labor Party national convention passed a resolution saying that Australia should play no part in confronting the dictatorship of Adolf Hitler should it come to war. So let us not try to pretend that the coalition was a great supporter of appeasement: that was the Labor Party's policy in 1938.

speech.para: The Australian government are unashamedly committed to taking a strong stand on national security. We have taken many tough decisions but we believe they have been necessary to protect Australia at home and abroad. In order to protect Australians at home, we clearly have to make substantial contributions to the international security situation. As a government, I think we have responded decisively to the `Islamo-fascist' attack on our value system, on the things that we all believe in—on our way of life and on the way of life of moderate Islam as well. We know that you have to be strong and that you have to be determined. We know that you have to try to lead in terms of public opinion and that you cannot afford to just look at an opinion poll and take a populist position; you have to be prepared to argue your case over a period of time. We have done some things which have been popular and we have done quite a lot of things which have been unpopular. One thing we have never been is weak. We have always been determined to do the right thing by this country, and I think we have been very successful in doing the right thing by this country.

After September 11, we invoked the ANZUS treaty; the ANZUS treaty was actually a coalition achievement. We were part of the coalition in Afghanistan. The SAS went to Afghanistan and they did a simply outstanding job. When their job was finished, they left. We contributed to the destruction of al-Qaeda's home base. We overthrew the vile sponsors of al-Qaeda, the Taliban regime, and we seriously degraded the capacity of the Taliban. We contributed to the overthrow of Saddam Hussein's regime in Iraq. We are proud of the role we played; we disarmed the regime and we freed its people. We transformed the international counter-proliferation agenda. Iraq will never again be able to use weapons of mass destruction against their own people or its neighbours. They will never be able to do it again. They will never be able to threaten their neighbours and the world again, either directly or indirectly.

We know that terrorist organisations are looking for weapons of mass destruction. The enormous success we have had in aggressively countering the proliferation of those weapons systems is now yielding some results in Libya, Iran, North Korea and Syria. To one degree or another—and it varies a bit from country to country—we are beginning to achieve things. We are proud of the role Australia has played, often quite a leading role, in prosecuting this agenda and prosecuting it very successfully. In terms of al-Qaeda, 3,000 terrorist suspects worldwide have been either detained or killed. Sixty-five per cent of al-Qaeda leaders—not Osama bin Laden or Mullah Omar but others—have been detained or, in some cases, killed. We have contributed to the detention of around 200 Jemaah Islamiah suspects. Hambali, the chief executive officer of Jemaah Islamiah, the South-East Asian counterpart of al-Qaeda, has been captured and $US200 million worth of terrorists' assets have been frozen.

Domestically, the government have strengthened our counterterrorism measures. Very importantly, we work very closely with our friends and neighbours in the region. I co-hosted with the Indonesian foreign minister the counter-terrorism meeting in Bali on 4 February. We set up the Jakarta centre for law enforcement cooperation. Since 9-11, we have signed nine bilateral memoranda of understanding on counterterrorism with Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, the Philippines, Fiji, Cambodia, East Timor, India and Papua New Guinea. The Leader of the Opposition did not mention any of those things in his speech. He never mentioned them—as though those things had never happened and are of no importance. To be fair, I would not have thought he would have a clue that those things had happened. The work that was done in the Bali investigation was an outstanding achievement.

Australia's leadership on these issues must remain. More than that, there must be great unity in the international effort to counter terrorism and terrorists, wherever they may be—Afghanistan, Iraq, Europe, as we saw in Madrid, or in South-East Asia. The only way to deal with these terrorists internationally is from a position of unity, and we all have to be prepared to make a contribution. I think that view is recognised around the globe. I think it is recognised by many people in the Australian Labor Party, but I do not think the Leader of the Opposition understands the issues. That gets to the heart of the Leader of the Opposition; I do not think he really understands what the issues at stake really are. Michael Howard, the opposition leader in the United Kingdom, said:

quote.para: Countries cannot insulate themselves from terrorist attack by opting out of the War on Terror. We cannot buy ourselves immunity by changing our foreign policy. Apart from the moral cowardice of that position, it can never work in practice.

speech.para: I think that is a very important statement, because Michael Howard is making it clear that, for all the disagreements he may have with Tony Blair, the opposition and the government in Britain are sticking together on these issues.

It is a very sad thing that, apparently without even consideration by the shadow cabinet, on the Mike Carlton show on 2UE, the Leader of the Opposition suddenly decided that that is not such a good idea. In the wake of the Madrid bombing, I would not have thought that that showed good or wise judgment. As I have said on many occasions over the last couple of days, we ask that the Leader of the Opposition think through the issues a bit more and get himself properly briefed. He has refused to have briefings. He has now decided to dig in; he definitely does not want any briefings. But he should get himself briefed and get to understand the issues. Once he understands the issues he will be able to develop his arguments and thoughts more coherently rather than stand at the dispatch box with the usual fusillade of opposition abuse about the government. You have to make an argument, not just tell everybody what fools people in the government are. You have to have an argument to put together. Mrs Yoriko Kawaguchi, the foreign minister of Japan, said:

quote.para: Caving in to threats will be just what the terrorists want. The international community needs to show that it is united in facing this threat.

speech.para: I thought that Andrew Sullivan from the Sunday Times of 21 March made a very important point. I quote it to the House because it is worth considering. He said:

quote.para: Nothing threatens al Qaeda or the Islamo-fascist terror network more than the possibility of ... constitutional democracy in Iraq. If Iraq succeeds, the entire dysfunction in the Middle East on which al Qaeda relies for its recruitment and growth would be in danger of unraveling. If Iraqis can achieve a semblance of a free and democratic society—with economic growth, political pluralism and religious freedom—then the al Qaeda model of theocratic fascism will lose whatever appeal it now has in that part of the world. Losing Afghanistan was bad enough for the Jihadists.

speech.para: That is a very important, significant statement by Andrew Sullivan, and the House should reflect on his words. Afghanistan and Iraq are great examples of what can be achieved in the Middle East. Islamo-fascism and dictatorship have been overthrown in those countries. Democracy is now beginning to be put in place in both of those countries. There is a way to go but democracy is on its way. I think we should do everything we can to support that and to resist the terrorists, particularly al-Qaeda and al-Qaeda related terrorists in Iraq—they are attacking not just coalition troops but also Iraqis—in order to ensure that the democratic processes in Iraq can take root so that those people can have what they want to achieve. If we can be successful, that will be an enormous strike against terrorism.

That brings me to what the Leader of the Opposition has been doing in the last few days. I think it is very sad that he has decided to try to politicise our troops in Iraq. I do not think that is necessary. I do not think that is going to be a great election-losing or election-winning position. This is not something that we should debate in the context of elections, particularly after what we have seen happen in Madrid. This is something we should think about very carefully. But it is part of a pattern in the way the Leader of the Opposition handles international relations issues. I accept that he does not know much about them—in which case I would have thought that he would tread carefully—but when we announced that we had negotiated a free trade agreement with America, his knee-jerk reaction was that he was opposed to it and would vote against it. In relation to Hicks and Habib, he floated the idea—he got away with this a bit, I thought, in the media—of retrospective criminal law so that Hicks and Habib could be prosecuted for a crime which is retrospectively applied. He now thinks that we should have a great big party political debate about our 850 or so troops in Iraq who are fighting off terrorists, or at least are contributing to those who are fighting off terrorists there, and protecting Australians who are in our embassy there.

I do not think that any of us will forget 3 December last year. It is a day that will go down in history. On 3 December the Leader of the Opposition had a press conference in the Labor Party caucus room and wrapped himself in the American flag. I think it is the first time in either the coalition party room or the Labor Party caucus room that the American flag has appeared. After all his anti-Americanism he decided that it was doing him political damage so, with the American flag there, he had a press conference, saying he loved America. Interestingly, it was also the same day that he went on the radio and, when he was asked about the troops in Iraq, said:

quote.para: Well I have got to get briefings from Foreign Affairs and from the Defence department about the detail. I can't fly in with a top of the head assessment, I have got to base my judgments on fact ... I have obviously got to get those sort of briefings before I can make any sort of considered judgment about what needs to be done.

speech.para: But he never sought the briefings. Why didn't he seek the briefings? He wanted briefings from Foreign Affairs and Defence. He didn't even ask for them. Then he came up with a policy. By the way, I do not know whether the policy has even gone to the shadow cabinet or to the caucus.

talk.start.para: —Don't they tell you?
—The member for Griffith does not support it—we know that from his letter. On 17 November the member for Griffith said:

quote.para: We should put our shoulder to the wheel in an effort to build a new Iraq.

speech.para: But the Leader of the Opposition says that we should cut and run.

Let me finally make this point: there are 35 countries which have troops in Iraq. Australia is an important country—Australia is not a little country; it is a significant country. New Zealand is one of the countries that have troops in Iraq. There is a debate about Spain, the Spanish election and the commitment of the Spanish Socialist Party to withdraw troops. As the Leader of the Opposition probably does not know but as many in the House will know, during the state funeral for the victims of the Madrid bombing, people like Colin Powell and Tony Blair had been meeting with the Prime Minister designate of Spain and pleading with him to reconsider his position on withdrawing troops from Iraq. He says that he will keep them there if there is a new UN resolution. That is an issue that needs to be played out. One of the key countries out of those 35 has an opposition leader who says, `We will withdraw the troops unconditionally.' The Leader of the Opposition's position on this issue is very untimely. It will play out internationally—people will notice this internationally. It will not be well received, not just by the Americans or the British—we can make jokes about them and how bad they all are and make jokes about the way they speak and the comments they make—but by other countries—

talk.start.para: —We make jokes about the way you speak.

—Okay, you make jokes about the way I speak. We used to be a multicultural society, but now the Labor Party says that you have to speak in a particular way. How very childish. What a schoolboy at play.
—Order! It being 4.30 p.m., I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, you would no doubt have noticed that I was absent from the House on the last two days of the previous sitting week. In what I hope has created a precedent, I was most grateful that the Chief Opposition Whip granted me what I would like to call grandparenting leave. On 26 February, my daughter Rebecca gave birth to my first grandchild—a healthy baby boy, Liam Geoffrey Hunt. Rebecca's husband, Chris, helped out for the first week after the new baby came home from hospital, but like many young couples with a mortgage to pay he needed to get back to his workplace.

speech.para: The first few weeks after giving birth can be a difficult time for a new mother, and extended family support is often needed at this time. Grandmothers are usually the first to offer assistance and, from my own experience as a new mother, they have a critical role to play. So it did not surprise me to read of the findings of a study by a Finnish university that grandmothers do play a vital role in improving the chances of grandchildren surviving to adulthood and having children of their own. Deborah Smith, the science editor of the Sydney Morning Herald, described the findings as helping to solve the puzzle of why humans are rare among animals in living well beyond child-bearing age. She said:

quote.para: They provide the first strong evidence for an explanation of the mystery known as the “grandmother hypothesis”—that life after menopause evolved because older woman can pass on their genes more effectively by helping raise their grandchildren, than by having more children themselves.

speech.para: The grandmother hypothesis, developed by the University of Utah's Professor Kirsten Hawkes, observes that human babies are unusual because they cannot feed themselves at weaning age. We grandmothers—and I should on behalf of my own mother, Lois Welsh, add great-grandmothers—know that we are important, but here we have scientific proof that we are the saviours of the human species. That makes us responsible for the ageing population and the need for the Treasurer's intergenerational reports.

The Treasurer has found a way to solve the problem. Instead of allowing grandmothers to help out with the raising of children, he wants us to work until we drop. But, as the study published in the journal Nature observed: if a woman over 50 was still alive when her children were producing, they had more children and they produced them about 2½ years earlier than families without a grandmother. So, at a time when we are concerned about Australia's declining birthrate and the older age at which Australian mothers are having their first child, we might consider the role of grandmothers.

We should remember that we are increasing the pension age for women to 65 and that family friendly work practices are rarely extended to grandparents. The present trend for grandparents to move up the coast and leave their grandchildren behind cannot be helpful either. It is time we took stock of our family relationships and how important for society these relationships are. We need to see ourselves as members of society, not as units of the economy, and to see the importance of these relationships. Fourteen per cent of Australian mothers suffer significant postnatal depression and a further 30 per cent suffer milder distress. Extended family can provide vital support to children and allow more effective treatment for sufferers of postnatal depression. I am pleased to add that the family and community affairs committee's recent report on children of separated families called for a greater role for grandparents in the child's relationship. So, before calling on grandparents to work until they drop, the Treasurer should consider the vital role of grandparents. The survival of the species depends on them. Welcome to the world and to our family, Liam Geoffrey Hunt.

talk.start.para: —I rise to talk about an issue of some concern to me—an issue that presented itself when I walked past the door of the member for Franklin, Mr Harry Quick. In particular, I was concerned about what I considered to be a highly offensive picture that was attached to the door of his office. This particular offensive picture equates George Bush with Osama bin Laden. It is in fact a photograph that has been digitally altered so that George W. Bush, the President of the United States, is portrayed to be Osama bin Laden. If you look closely at what is implicit in this particular picture on the door of the member for Franklin's office, you see that what the member for Franklin is saying is not simply that he does not like George W. Bush, which all in this chamber would know, but that he is attempting to portray a democratically elected president of the United States as being akin to a murderous leader of a terrorist organisation such as Osama bin Laden. It is an outright disgrace, and the member for Franklin ought to be condemned for having this type of outrageous and scandalous digital photograph on his office door in this, our nation's parliament.

speech.para: We know that the member for Franklin does not like George Bush. He is on the record in this chamber as stating in the grievance debate of 10 January last year that he viewed George W. Bush as being:

quote.para: ... a Wild West gun-toting Texan bounty hunter masquerading as a US president and desperate for a rerun of the Gulf War.

speech.para: In fact, last year the member for Franklin had to be chastised by the then Leader of the Opposition because he was threatening to not even be civil enough to show common decency when President Bush visited Australia. The member for Franklin has gone further. In the leadup to, during and now after the successful liberation of the people of Iraq by American, British and Australian forces, he has paraded about the country in various protests condemning the forces for their efforts to bring human rights and freedom to the Iraqi people. In fact, the member for Franklin has labelled coalition forces as `the coalition of the killing'. He called Australia, along with Britain and the United States, the `immoral minority'. In the grievance debate of 18 March last year, he said:

quote.para: Why do we have to race to join the coalition of the willing—I call it `the coalition of the killing'—three Anglo-Saxon nations out of the 200-plus nations in the United Nations ... Australia, the United Kingdom and the USA are the immoral minority. History will long note the integrity of those who stand against this immoral war.

speech.para: But let us look at this more closely. Let us look at the actual crux of this issue. Let us test the member for Franklin's belief in the moral equivalency of the democratically elected President of the United States with the self-appointed leader of a murderous underground terrorist organisation such as al-Qaeda. The Oklahoma City National Memorial Institute for the Prevention of Terrorism database lists on its web site that since 1 January 1997 there have been 10 terrorist attacks attributable to al-Qaeda; the number of people murdered by the al-Qaeda organisation totals 3,419, or nearly 3,500—and they were not killed innocently; and the number of people who have been injured by the al-Qaeda organisation led by Osama bin Laden totals 5,336. That makes a total number of fatalities and people who have been injured of some 8,755.

The member for Franklin deserves to be condemned for portraying President Bush, the leader of a democratic country, as the moral equivalent of Osama bin Laden. It is an absolute disgrace. The Leader of the Opposition owes it to the people of Australia to ensure that they understand that the Labor Party does not support the member for Franklin. The silence of the Leader of the Opposition will demonstrate that the Labor Party stands behind the member for Franklin in indicating that George Bush is the equivalent to Osama bin Laden. It is important to remember that the figures I have cited represent only the incidents that are directly attributable to al-Qaeda. They do not include figures from the groups al-Qaeda has trained and funded and from terrorist attacks that have been masterminded by, for example, Jemaah Islamiah. In short, the member for Franklin ought to be condemned for insinuating that a democratic country's leader, like George W. Bush, no matter what his politics, is the equivalent of Osama bin Laden. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Last week the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs handed down a report entitled A hand up not a hand out: renewing the fight against poverty. It devoted its chapter 12 to youth and students issues. At 12.94 it states:

quote.para: Whilst it is acknowledged that education is an important pathway out of poverty, many young people cannot access education or cannot complete their education because of a lack of financial resources.

speech.para: I wish to share with the House tonight local experiences of the effects of financial hardship and family poverty on education and educational possibilities. Community Information Whittlesea has been running emergency relief programs since 1997. Recently it completed a report on the reasons that people seek emergency relief. The number of clients assisted since 1997 by CIW has increased by 27 per cent, with an average of 60 clients per month being turned away. Of the people who sought and received emergency relief: with housing related poverty, 48.7 per cent paid between a quarter and a half of their income on the cost of their housing and 35.1 per cent paid more than half of their income, and most of these people lived in private rental arrangements; 37 per cent sought relief due to interruptions of Centrelink benefits; three-quarters were parents with children; and 27 per cent sought relief for children's school expenses—fees, books and uniforms.

St Vincent de Paul and Community Information Diamond Valley, in conjunction with Emergency Relief Victoria, did a study into the impact of school costs on low-income families with primary and secondary school aged children in 2004. Victorian Emergency Relief agencies involved in the survey indicated that 84 per cent of agencies had experienced an increase in demand for emergency relief to cover education costs; and 91.3 per cent of people who utilise emergency relief for back to school assistance were on pension or benefit and 8.7 per cent were part-time workers. The majority of emergency relief assistance for back to school costs was spent on books, clothes and uniforms and shoes. The cost of education in the last three to seven years has had an impact on low-income families due to the restructuring of the education maintenance allowance and the introduction of voluntary contributions, transport costs and the impact of the GST.

This week the Age newspaper highlighted the SRC Breakfast Club at the La Trobe University. The Student Representative Council started the breakfast club two years ago due to a growing concern with student poverty and that students were going without food to make ends meet. The club runs a breakfast club every Wednesday, and each week something like 200 students avail themselves of that service.

The report of the Senate committee goes to the type of things that confront students—the impact of student debt, especially at the tertiary level, and the way that their results are affected by concerns about their spending habits. The report quotes a vice-chancellors' report from a number of years ago that indicated that something like 28 per cent of students who were in financial hardship went, for instance, without proper heating. A number of students find it difficult to get to classes, because they have to have part-time work to make ends meet. The impact on the way in which they are able to successfully study is growing.

These are things that we should realise when we are putting in place proper public policy about education. We should not talk in the abstract and fail to remember these challenges that confront many students who, as reports say, are trying to better themselves through the development of skills and education. These issues impact not only on students, making it difficult for them to make ends meet, but also on their families and their families' budgets with the sacrifices made on the students' behalf.

Another local project I have taken a great deal of interest in is a breakfast program at the Mill Park secondary college. Unfortunately a few years ago that program went through difficulties with its resourcing. There was an argument about whether or not local government should make a contribution. At that time, I said that I thought these things, like many things that communities try to achieve, should be seen as a partnership and that all spheres of government should perhaps look at their effort to see whether they could be involved. Then, not only through government but also through the community, we will be able to see some form of success. I highlighted at that time that, in contrast with the United States, where the federal government since the 1970s has funded a universal school breakfast program, we have no such thing in Australia—and I think we should. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Following my eye accident in November and my return to work, I undertook to do what I could in the community to highlight the very dangerous practice of not wearing safety equipment when you are using chemicals such as hydrochloric acid. I took the opportunity to do just that at some of the schools in my electorate, particularly the primary schools, when I was invited to those schools for various reasons, such as presenting an Australian flag. My reason for being here tonight is to acknowledge the compassion and real concern that was shown to me by students at one of the schools that I visited.

speech.para: This particular school is the rural school in the little village of Laggan, north of Crookwell. It has 55 students and three female teachers, and the principal, Ms Lyn Collett, is a very dedicated, professional teacher. These young students were very upset about the fact that I had injured my eye—keeping in mind that these are primary school children aged between six and 11 years old. They undertook between them to design and present to me some 50 eye patches because they had heard about my competition. The plastic eye patch that I wear over my eye gets extremely hot so I was looking for some very light alternatives and ran a competition for senior people to design and make a lightweight eye patch for me and receive a bottle a vintage wine. Children under 18 years of age, of course, could not participate because of the alcoholic beverages—because it is unlawful, and quite rightfully so—so I decided I would donate a music CD and a book to the under-18 winner of the competition.

When I went to the Laggan Public School they presented me with about 50 eye patches. They are typical of the imagination of young children, particularly our most precious asset, the very young children in this great country of ours. Some of them are quite funny. The one that I am wearing today—incidentally, I promised those young children I would wear one every day in appreciation of the considerable effort they went to to make them—is another colourful one, and it says `Poor Alby'. I think that gives you an indication of just how caring young children are.

I have also taken the opportunity to visit a number of schools, including that school, and talk to them about the dangers of chemicals and how they should listen to their mums and dads when they are talking about the dangers of chemicals. Some of those children were quietly, in their very concerned way, asking me about how it happened and what my eye looked like, and then they finally got around to the point where they asked me to lift up my eye patch, which I do. Invariably you get one or two young children who do a huge intake of breath once they see the little bit of plastic on my eye, but they are very concerned and very anxious to learn about how it happened, what it did, and whether in future I am likely to be able to focus normally. I think that gives you an indication of the wonderful way in which young children are taught in our schools today and the direction that their parents and teachers are taking them in a very difficult world climate.

I want to pay tribute to the teachers and parents of those caring small children because, as I said, they were obviously worried about my eye and eager to learn how the accident happened. I would also like to use this opportunity to thank all of my parliamentary colleagues on both sides of the House, including the crossbenchers, who were concerned and wished me well in my recovery with my eye. I have got a long way to go yet. I would also like to acknowledge the contributions, concerns and good wishes sent to me by people in the Senate from across the broad spectrum of politics. It is very important to ensure that, when a colleague or one of our peers or friends has an accident, they know that people do care for them. I certainly do know and I would like to thank you for that. In the meantime, thank you once again to those young children for making me these beautiful patches. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —A draft management plan for saltwater crocodiles has been prepared by the Northern Territory government and presented to the Commonwealth government for consideration. This draft plan allows for the trial of a tourism based crocodile safari hunting program that permits 25 adult crocodiles over 4.2 metres in length to be harvested each year. The Territory government has drafted this proposal in the knowledge that allowing a limited level of crocodile hunting, if well managed, will provide significant economic benefit to Indigenous communities as well as pastoralists in the Top End.

speech.para: Already tourism based on the hunting of other animals in the Northern Territory contributes $15 million annually to the economy. The safari hunting of crocodiles will increase the opportunities available to Aboriginal land-holders to develop viable businesses of their own on their own land. As such, the plan has received support from the Northern Land Council, and the Tiwi Land Council. I am sure I do not need to remind the House of the importance of ensuring that Indigenous Australians, especially in the Top End, have access to opportunities like this. I think it is also important to appreciate how the crocodile population—their increasing numbers—impacts on the ability of Indigenous communities to carry out traditional activities.

The Northern Territory government has written to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, David Kemp, requesting that he support the safari hunting proposal. This afternoon, I understand there was a meeting which involved Minister Kemp, Ministers Burns and Scrymgour from the Northern Territory, Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association representative Tony Searles, Matthew Ryan from Maningrida, and Dr Graham Webb, an acknowledged international crocodile expert.

Concern has been raised previously about the sustainability of crocodile safari hunting. This has been considered by the Territory in drafting the management plan. Further, the Parks and Wildlife Commission of the Northern Territory has had considerable success in conserving and managing crocodile populations under the current allowance for crocodile harvesting. Already in existence in the Northern Territory are safari hunting programs for feral buffalo and banteng cattle. The crocodile hunting safaris would be run along similar lines.

This trial could be conducted while maintaining the international agreements concerning the protection of wildlife, to which Australia is a signatory. The draft management plan considers animal welfare standards and requires adherence to a code of conduct. The methods of harvesting proposed under the plan are the same as those used by the commercial crocodile hunters who are already operating. The methods of hunting provided for by the Territory government ensure a humane harvest and a minimal risk of injured crocodiles escaping.

The hunted crocodiles will be taken as part of the quota that has already been issued for harvesting adult crocodiles. Safari hunting will not result in more animals being taken than is the case under the present program. The draft management plan commits the Territory government to sustainable hunting practices, including the establishment of areas where the harvesting of crocodiles and their eggs are prohibited, covering Kakadu, Gregory, Gurig, Mary River, Litchfield and other national parks and catchment areas.

Conservative quotas for the harvest of adult crocodiles and their eggs have been set. Already 600 crocodiles per year are permitted to be harvested, representing less than one per cent of the crocodile population of the Territory. The quotas for safari hunting of crocodiles are equally conservatively set. It is estimated by the Territory government that there are 1,750 crocodiles over four metres in length in the Northern Territory. This trial permits the harvesting of just 25 of them.

The final version of the management plan must be approved by the Commonwealth to allow for the export of crocodile products. The minister's final decision on the plan is yet to be made. The decision is due by mid-April of this year. I understand that the meeting with the minister went very well this afternoon. I am hopeful—and I am sure the Northern Territory government and community are hopeful—that when he makes his final decision he will approve this management plan and allow for this harvesting of crocodiles in the way which has been described. It is worth noting that I was just talking to Mr Searles from the Cattlemen's Association. He says that he has to provide for the cattle on the flood plains. They estimate that they lose five in 1,000 of their herd to crocodiles each year.

talk.start.para: —On Tuesday and Wednesday of this week the Leader of the Opposition announced that a Labor government would bring troops home from Iraq by Christmas. It is a nice catchy phrase and it has a long history redolent of World War I. He was asked to do it by Bob Brown, he was pushed to do it by Mike Carlton on 2UE and it was market tested by Hawker Britton. What does this say about decision making under a Latham government? What can we expect from decision making on national security from a Latham government? Importantly, what does it say about how decisions will be made and what the quality of those decisions will be? On one of the most important responsibilities that a national government has, the deployment of service personnel, we have a decision that was taken without the shadow cabinet. It was done with no analysis, no briefings, no consideration of the security situation in Iraq and in the absence of the most experienced member of the Labor Party in national security, the member for Brand.

speech.para: Quite simply, it is wrong to put an arbitrary deadline on the withdrawal of troops from Iraq. Let us look back at how this decision was made. When the Leader of the Opposition was speaking to Mike Carlton on 2UE on Tuesday, he supported bringing troops home `when they have finished their responsibilities for the post-war reconstruction'—a respectable position. Under persistent questions from Mike Carlton, that changed to, `If there is a change of government, we would be hoping to have them back by Christmas certainly'. That position further changed on Wednesday to `definitely home by Christmas'.

This is an important break in bipartisanship. It illustrates the erratic leadership of the member for Werriwa, which Australia cannot afford while it is engaged in a war on terror. The day the Labor caucus decided to elect the Leader of the Opposition over the former defence minister and former member of the cabinet security committee, the member for Brand, is the day they opened themselves up to the charge that they do not consider national security a priority. Quite simply, the Leader of the Opposition is not qualified to take charge on national security, and we have seen that this week. Our worry is that he will do to Australia what he did to Liverpool Council.

The issue here is not whether or not to support the war in Iraq; the issue is whether Australia should play any role in finishing the job. The Leader of the Opposition has said in his defence that the Labor Party's first priority is always the defence of Australia. This is a glib, motherhood statement. We are talking about 850 service personnel in Iraq—peacekeepers, administrators, people defending airfields and so on—out of a total ADF personnel of 50,000. The statement is glib and it is hogwash.

It is quite possible that the Leader of the Opposition imagines himself as a modern day John Curtin bringing home the troops from the Middle East to defend Australia—you might ask: against what? Contrast his leadership with the leadership shown by John Curtin. John Curtin understood the importance of the American alliance. In December 1941 he famously wrote:

quote.para: Without any inhibitions of any kind, I make it quite clear that Australia looks to America free of any pangs as to our traditional links or kinship with the United Kingdom.

speech.para: John Curtin did not take backward steps in the face of a threat. John Curtin was a man who saw things through. Australia has always been a country that sees things through—a country that finishes the job. We have never been a country to cut and run.

I know that the Leader of the Opposition likes reading books, and he likes reading books to children. Might I suggest that he does what former Labor leader Paul Keating used to do—read a biography of Winston Churchill. If he reads about Churchill's wartime leadership he will find that there were months and months of nothing but bad news. But John Curtin, Franklin Roosevelt and Winston Churchill were never men to cut and run during their wartime leadership. We can only contrast the Leader of the Opposition's comments with those of another opposition leader, Michael Howard. He said:

quote.para: Whatever my disagreements with Tony Blair, any government that I lead will not flinch in its determination to win the War against Terror wherever it has to be fought.

speech.para: We want the Labor Party to join us in the war on terror. This should never have been a party political issue. The Labor Party should rethink their decision and do what is in the best interests of Australia and the people of Iraq.

talker.name: Bailey, Fran, MP
FRAN BAILEY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —In the 25 seconds or so that are left I want to raise a very important issue in the House. It concerns the topic of gender reassignment, which a constituent contacted me about. This amounts to nothing more than mutilation of human beings. I will be speaking more on this topic at a later time.
—Order! It being 5 p.m., the debate is interrupted.

para.inline: House adjourned at 5.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: to move:

motion.para: That this House—

interjection.para: (1) notes that:
(a) recent statistics show that first home buyers in Australia now make up only 11.6 per cent of all homebuyers, down from 24 per cent two years ago;
(b) the drip-feed land release policies of the NSW Carr Labor Government have pushed land prices to unaffordable levels for first home buyers in Sydney;

(c) the NSW State Government took $3.5 billion in Stamp Duty from homebuyers in NSW in the 2002/03 financial year and that all State and Territory Governments took $8.4 billion from all Australian Homebuyers;
(d) the median Sydney house price is now $460,000 and the stamp duty payable on that purchase value is $16,190;
(e) Stamp Duty is the single biggest impediment to first home buyers; and
